summary: Adrift in space with no food or water, Tony Stark sends a message to Pepper Potts as his oxygen supply starts to dwindle. Meanwhile, the remaining Avengers -- Thor, Black Widow, Captain America and Bruce Banner -- must figure out a way to bring back their vanquished allies for an epic showdown with Thanos -- the evil demigod who decimated the planet and the universe.

reviews.content: Just a small step down from Infinity War. The top 5 best MCU movies are (in no particular order): Infinity War, Endgame, Iron Man 1, Guardians 1 and Civil War.

Avengers: Endgame - Falling Short of Expectations

Regrettably, this installment of the Avengers franchise falls short. Despite my appreciation for the previous films and some enjoyable and humorous moments in this one, it fails to maintain the momentum of its predecessors. The story lacks the excitement and energy of the previous movies, and the dialogue is uninteresting, resulting in dull and tedious sequences.

The Avengers appear to be a clumsy and awkward group, posing for a photo like a bad high school reunion. However, I, like many others, have been a fan of the Avengers franchise for years, though this particular film did not meet my expectations.

The character of Captain Marvel, with her overwhelming powers, appears to be overdone and simplistic, with no real challenge or reason for her to lose a fight.

One may question whether a large collective of all the heroes was truly necessary. It seems that it was not.

Furthermore, certain scenes drag on for too long, adding nothing to the already thin plot. Additionally, the absence of Dr. Strange, who possessed a crucial aspect of the story, was disappointing, as he hardly had anything to say and made only a brief appearance.

Avengers Endgame" is an epic conclusion to the Marvel Cinematic Universe's Infinity Saga. The film's intricate storytelling, stunning visuals, and incredible action sequences provide an immersive experience for viewers. The outstanding performances by the cast, particularly Robert Downey Jr. and Chris Evans, add to the emotional depth of the film. Although the runtime is lengthy, the pacing is well-balanced, and the payoff is worth the wait. Overall, "Avengers Endgame" is a must-see for fans of the MCU and an excellent conclusion to an epic saga.

Iron Man accepting the end and sacrifyng for everything has his weight, remember that he was all the contrary in Iron Man, so this is the result of his growth as character.  And he has the best things of the movie, the fact that he has a son shows how really the tima has passed in that 5 years. Being the only one who did not get involved in Thanos' tragedy, he feels the pain of having lost so many, but decides to move on, not out of cowardice, but to accept a sad fate, which despite this, risked bringing them back. with Scott's idea.
The scene that meet his father, even we didn't know that relationship, it's nice and Tone looks really happy with that, How they both talk about fatherhood and how Tony teaches his father about it makes it even more special, also showing us how his vision of his father has changed when he saw that he raised him in the best way he could, despite sometimes being someone tough
Seriously, why you show that Steve left Peggy in the past if in the end he will be back. I understand, the end represents the character finally recovering the past, but the first movies of Captain America, The First Avneger and The Winther Solider: They showed us that the past cannot be recovered and they emphasized that tragedy of the character, that now he can return with Peggy, it simply reduces this arc of the character that was built for years.
Thor is a comic relief from his third installment, he doesn't have much to contribute, however it is a consequence of what Thanos did to people, leaving Thor completely defeated.
I understand the concept, but it is executed in a very poor way, yes, it is exact with Thor Ragnarok, but not with the previous films that brought Thor as a more mature character, stoic although funny at times, they could have treated him as a subject who lost hope having seen all the tragedy of his people, surrendered perhaps meditating, or even dedicating himself to killing beasts on earth in a desperate search to find a purpose.
Thanos was totally replaced by another villain, he, but from 2014
This movie was planned as an event, but just the beginning ruined part of the moview for me, why did you killed Thanos at the principle after anticipating him for more of 10 years and introduce a new villain in seconds?
It may be the same character, but it is not, it has the memories introduced in a terrible way, but not the experience of the other character, it feels like a rushed clone, they change their motivation in seconds, losing everything built in Infinity War
The other character doesn't have an special argument and even the trama contradicts part of their growth in the anterior movies.
The time travel has it's problems, they explain one thing by Bruce Banner, but we can see other when Steve Rogers returns to the present.
In conclusion, Avengers Endgame doesn't look like an Endgame... And it didn't have to be, I know some people wouldn't like it because they're only interested in the excitement of a franchise, but it could easily have been more artistic, which is what Marvel is looking for right now, if the end had been to accept the loss of all those people, giving more weight to the snap and the defeat of the avengers, as well as that things cannot always be avenged. Sometimes tragedies are inevitable, there are wounds that cannot heal.

Avengers: End game is a 2019 American superhero film produced by Marvel Studios and directed by Anthony and Joe Russo. The film is an exceptional movie that delivers a truly epic conclusion to the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU). The film's storyline is both emotional and action- packed, with several memorable moments that have become iconic in the MCU. It also does an excellent job of bringing all of the superheroes together all the different plot threads and character arcs from the previous Marvel films to fight again the evil who is Thanos and his group providing a satisfying conclusion to the Marvel Cinematic Universe's Infinity Saga.
One of the most impressive things about this film is how it balances humor and heart and this film has lots of comedic moments but also explores deeper themes of loss, sacrifice, and family. Moreover, the film is stunning with some of the most impressive action sequences ever seen in a superhero movie. The special effect are top-notch, and the use of music, lighting and sound design creats a truly immersive experience.
Overall, Avengers: End Game is a masterpiece of a film that successfully brings MCU's first saga to a close. It's a must-watch for fans of superheroes movies and MCU.

"Avengers: Endgame" (2019) is the final film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe's Infinity Saga, and it brings to a close the storylines of many of the franchise's most beloved characters. The film takes the audience on a journey through time and space, as the surviving Avengers attempt to restore order to the universe and defeat the evil Thanos.

The themes of sacrifice, friendship, and the power of hope are at the forefront of the film, and the filmmakers handle these themes with the care and respect that the characters and their arcs deserve. The tone of the film is grandiose and epic, with moments of levity and humor to balance the film's more serious moments.

The acting is, as always, superb, with standout performances from the entire cast. Robert Downey Jr. brings a sense of closure to his decade-long portrayal of Tony Stark, while Chris Evans delivers a powerful farewell to his character Steve Rogers. The characters are well-developed and, for fans of the franchise, it is a treat to see so many of them on-screen together.

The direction is top-notch, with the Russo brothers delivering some truly awe-inspiring action sequences that will have you on the edge of your seat. The score is fitting and emotive, adding to the film's overall sense of grandeur and importance. The cinematography is stunning, capturing the scope and scale of the film's epic battles and locations.

The production design is outstanding, with each set piece and location looking like they have been lifted straight from the pages of a comic book. The special effects are, as always, state-of-the-art, and the film's final battle is a visual feast. The editing is smooth, keeping the film's pace moving at a breakneck speed, while the dialog is sharp and witty.

Overall, "Avengers: Endgame" is a fitting conclusion to the Marvel Cinematic Universe's Infinity Saga and a love letter to fans of the franchise. It is a film that will leave audiences feeling satisfied and emotional, and it is a testament to the power of the superhero genre to tell compelling and emotionally resonant stories. This movie is exceptional and a truly unforgettable experience.

"Avengers: Endgame" is a phenomenal conclusion to the Marvel Cinematic Universe's epic Infinity Saga. The movie perfectly combines high-stakes action with emotional character moments to create a satisfying and thrilling experience for fans of the franchise.

One of the biggest strengths of the film is its incredible cast, who bring their A-game in portraying beloved characters such as Iron Man, Captain America, Thor, and the rest of the Avengers. Their performances are both heartwarming and heart-wrenching, especially as they navigate the aftermath of the events of "Avengers: Infinity War".

The pacing of the film is also masterful, as it manages to balance its intense action sequences with quieter character moments that give the audience a chance to catch their breath and reflect on what's happening. The story itself is also well-crafted, with plenty of surprises and unexpected twists that keep the audience engaged and guessing until the very end.

Additionally, the movie's visual effects are stunning, with impressive action scenes that feel truly epic in scale. The final battle in particular is a visual feast that will leave fans cheering.

Overall, "Avengers: Endgame" is a triumphant conclusion to a decade of Marvel storytelling. It offers closure and resolution for beloved characters while also setting the stage for the next phase of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. With its great cast, thrilling action, and emotional storytelling, it's a must-see for fans of the franchise and a testament to the power of superhero movies.

This movie isn't just a journey of going through 21 movies to get to End Game, but it's the years it took to get here, I actually remember me and my friends discussing everything about the Infinity stones when Iron Man came out and all about the comics, and at the time it was just talk but back then if I knew the journey I would experience l through all the movies that came I wouldn't have believed it, what they did was unprecedented. I have to be honest there was even times that I was so dedicated to it being like the comics and actually hating it at the time because I thought it should be more like the comics but I still continued to watch to see where it goes and I never regreted it at all and I'm really eager to see where it goes even with a few speculations on on what could happen next. The wait for this movie was absolutely nerve-racking because I needed to know what have happened and I even went to lengths as to only seeing the trailer once and to avoid any speculation on every social network because I didn't want any spoiler. When I went to the theatre to watch this it was one of the best experiences I have had, the only thing was that I booked this movie so far in advance that by time the movie's release date changed earlier so I went days after its release date yet the atmosphere was if it was the first day, I couldn't believe how everyone was more energetic than ever and how there was people dressing to the theme of the movie. Usually I don't like when people would interrupt the movie by being loud and annoying but I actually enjoyed how everyone was reacting to everything, and nobody was actually scared to show any emotion for what was happening in the movie theatre and the we would collectively cheer at certain scenes. No matter what anyone would say about this movie, whether it's slower, or more different than the Infinity War but this movie brought so many people together even when the movie was already out we all wouldn't even post spoilers for each other because we all didn't want to ruin it for someone else, it's amazing how a movie like this brought us all together in unity. 

This movie is such a rollercoaster ride of emotions, it shows us at them at their lowest point to make the fight mean so much more because they know they cannot lose again. The cinematography is absolutely amazing, I feel like the effect are far more solid in this movie than Infinity war, all details are more sharper and clearer, and everything especially the end battle is so cinematic. That end battle is the reason why this movie was needed to see in IMAX 3D, I feel sorry for those who missesd out on the IMAX experience. The sound was far better aswell especially the beginning and the ending, the score was just perfect and the ending you were so focused on the battle that you would even forget how about all the amazing sound effects. The story as actually emotional and feel more solid for a final ending, Infinity war felt like an event but this more like a story, which I think was absolutely brilliant because we go to see very upclose to the amazing performances that everyone gave, everyone is talking about Robert Downey Jr but Paul Rudd and Scarlett Johansson have such an amazing performance, it's so underrated. Watching all the movies from the MCU makes this movie far more emotional than ever because you get really emotionally invested in all the characters that was snapped away and it feels so surreal to not see them throughout the entire movie so when you see them for the first time return is such an emotional experience, I think the three hour length worked in that favour because you really feel the wait and when you finally see everyone return you just want to cry.

Endgame does indeed have a really solid final act, featuring some stellar and complex CGI, intricate blocking and an emotional gut-punch.  However, Endgame is also 3 full hours long, and because the movie opens up with Thanos being killed and his power being unable to be reversed, and thus, it turns into a Time Travel/Paradox film.  This in itself isn't a problem, beyond the fact that it opens up by having our heroes IMMEDIATELY accomplish what they couldn't do throughout the ENTIRE previous film (with twice as many of them!), but this also results in the film spending 2 hours just screwing around.  It creates logical fallacy after logical fallacy, and doesn't even do the slightest to try to repair them, making anyone paying even the slightest attention to the logistics a massive headache.  What's worse is that ALL of these logical fallacies that the film just dumps onto the audience with reckless abandon are SOLELY done to generate laughs.  This is not just involving the cross of their own time-streams, but things like Past Thanos discovering Earth's plan to stop him ~5 years in the past.... only to have him opt to wait to the present day to attack Earth..  Lastly, while I actually dig the spirit of the female-hero moment, I think it would've worked a lot better if it didn't open up with all of them lining up, knowing that they had a moment to shine.  Seriously, I just imagine all of the female heroes fighting, and then being like "Oh wait wait - stop fighting, our moment's coming up -- Quick, get in position!"  However, the movie isn't exactly a loss, and like I said, the final act is engaging and catharsis, at least for the most part.  And watching Thanos punch a....certain someone clean across the battlefield was just awesome!  I could watch that bit all day!  Seriously though, there's actually quite a good movie in Endgame - it's just buried in literal hours of filler that only act to make the story contradictory with itself, which is sad because these annoyances were not needed whatsoever.

This film gave me the best movie experience of my life I remember 4/26/19 like it was yesterday all the crowd reactions & the satisfaction I got seeing the end of the Infinity Saga. I find it interesting how the snap is something that affected everyone in the MCU no character was safe from it they have been affected by it in some way which is awesome. & this film isn't just fanservice it also gives amazing character moments like Thor getting depressed after the Avengers lost to Thanos in Infinity War he doesn't easily just lose all the fat & is back in peak shape he keeps doubting himself & feeling like he isn't worthy since he could have stopped Thanos if he aimed for the head at the end of Infinity War so when he is given the opportunity to fix things he helps out but still doubts himself luckily he gets to go back to 2013 & talk with his mom who tells Thor it isn't his fault for what happened & That "The Measure of success of a person or a hero is how well they succeed at who they are" & too make sure of this Thor reaches out & is so happy that his iconic hammer comes to him proving he is still worthy which repairs his self esteem. Another moment I loved was Tony meeting his father again since this time he knows his father did love him with hindsight so getting the chance to meet him again before his death must have been great for him since he did say in Civil War that not getting more time with his father is one of his biggest regrets. While the finale might be a big dumb CGI war that's a mess it did give us a great conclusion for Tony he sacrifices himself to save the Universe & having everyone tell him that he can finally rest knowing that Thanos is gone & everyone he cares about is safe kneeling in front of him during his final moments were beautiful I swore I could imagine he was hearing Yinsen's words in his head from Iron Man "Don't waste your life, Stark" before passing away.

What a movie. Potentially an unpopular opinion but I personally think Avengers: Endgame is better than Avengers: Infinity War. This movie begins opening up so much possibilities and raises levels of expectations for future MCU films. It is that good.

Even though the movie is 3 hours long, the watch doesn't necessarily feel that way.

Avengers: Endgame tried desperately to appeal to their fans by having an entire plot surrounding time travel and meanwhile showcasing all those scenes from previous movies, and that was supposed to be emotional and an amazing fan service. However, I'm just not a fan of time travel movies and I honestly think Marvel could have done more in exploring themes and techniques, like the much more original Infinity War where Thanos was being portrayed as a tragic hero and almost a psychological drama of him versus the entire world, instead, we just got a regular blockbuster movie again where characters just flew around in 'quantum realm' and then did all those ridiculous things, and then of course led to a third act where all those CGIs threw themselves into each other.
I genuinely raised my expectation for Marvel movies a bit after seeing Infinity War where a deep investigation of Thanos war conquest, ideological struggle and his mental state was presented with fantastic scenes and music scores. But then Endgame just regressed into yet another blockbuster movie with little to no thought behind. All the psychological struggle and deep reflection simply gave in to let the more amateurish and childish elements surfaced, for the sake of making children scream and buy a toy.
The Russos could have done more with it, but they didn't. The movie was not as good as people said it was. For me, it was not a satisfactory conclusion to the saga.

This is a movie for the fans. Avengers: Endgame is the culmination of over a decade of character development and worldbuilding; packed full of action, exceptional visuals, fan service, and pandering to fans' nostalgia from past movies. The problem is that all of it rests on the shoulders of a relatively weak and contrived time-travel plot that doesn't make much sense and breaks its own rules within the movie multiple times.

I'm not American so I didn't grow up reading comic books about superheroes, and I wouldn't count myself as a big MCU fan either given that I marathoned my way through the movies only recently. So, clearly, this movie was not made for me, but I can appreciate what it means to long-time fans of the MCU. If I were in their shoes, I would also ignore the parts that made no sense—even if said parts referred to the very foundation the movie's plot is built on, which is the case with Avengers: Endgame—because the pay-off is there.

a conclusion to over a decades worth of storytelling, it's got a lot to live up to, and it's about as good as you could really hope for it to be. Overall, I really do like Infinity War better. At the end of the day, Infinity War was just a wildly new experience, it was such a gamechanger and crowd-pleaser. Not only that, Infinity War I think had a better final battle. This final battle, while boasting the biggest ensemble of Marvel heroes we've ever seen on screen, is weirdly dark and muddied in CGI scenery compared to the battle at Wakanda from Infinity War. Also I hate Professor Hulk, he's just not that fun. Okay so those are my criticisms, what did I like about the movie? I guess everything else? The time travel plot let's us revisit and honor some old moments in Marvel with a new lens in sort of a Back to the Future Part 2 way that's a lot of fun, and it brings back some characters I didn't think we'd ever see again. The movie has a big emotional core, and a climactic end that is godamn powerful. This movie juggles a lot. Seriously this is like watching someone juggle 10 flaming chainsaws, it's a godamn miracle it works at all. That it works this well is even more of a miracle. It's an imperfect movie, but perfectly satisfying conclusion to this arc of the Marvel saga.

Directed by the brothers Anthony and Joe Russo; "Avengers: Endgame" went out in 2019, being the penultimate movie of the third MCU's phase. Starring some of the biggest Hollywood actors like Robert Downey Jr., Chris Evans or Scarlett Johansson, the ,181 minutes long, movie is based on a Stan Lee story. The film took places just after Avengers Infinity War where 50% of the world's population has died. The rest of the superhero group "Avengers" tried to finally beat the bad guy Thanos. The Plot can look Utterly complicated but in fact, with all the others MCU movie all take Sens and the plot looks way better and perfectly made. In facts they used all the characters well and give them all a custom end. I loved that movie and in my way it's a stunning, amusing and fast-paced film. The acting is also highly impressive, and the ending is outstanding: it gives goosebumps. We feel the giant budget and it has been used very well when we see the specials effects which are also outstanding. To conclude I'll say that the filming techniques are superb like the close plan at the end or the panorama plans to see all the army. And the photography looks profoundly elaborate as the luminosity or the settings.  So I recommend it as well without hesitation.

I am a late arrival to the Avengers scene, but I was able to observe all the hype directed towards this move as it was happening. Was this movie deserving of the hype? Was it a satisfying conclusion to the Infinity saga that has dominated movie screens for 3 presidential administrations? I would say the answer is yes to both those questions.

First off, this movie is king and barely has downtime. The fighting itself doesn't take up the majority of the screen time, but the plot is constantly moving forward. I was quite surprised how the plot mostly focused on undoing Thanos's actions from the previous movie rather than defeating him. His character is dealt with quite early in the movie, so his return at the end was welcome. 

The thing the movie does best is show the respect due to its characters that have been with them since the beginning. The new(er) characters get plenty of time to shine, but the veteran characters are really front and center. Also, this movie is not afraid to kill off characters you love. It feels like the directors knew we were mature enough to understand that not everyone can have a happy ending all the time. 

The only downside of this movie is how many previous details you have to remember from the tons of movies that came before it. I understand you can't spoon feed your audience every little detail, but man, there are a lot of characters and plot lines you have to remember if you're going to get every detail spelled out in this movie. All-in-all, this was a fantastic movie. It will be remembered for a long time to come as a grand event on the silver screen that capped off a series millions of people around the globe fell in love with.
This movie is the turning point of the Avengers story, and as sad as I am at the end of the movie, the end was surprising and exciting for the future of this story at the same time.

Avengers: Endgame is an American superhero film. Based on Marvel Comics' The Avengers, produced by Marvel Studios. and distributed by Walt Disney Studios Motion Picts. It is the twenty-second film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. and is the final and secondary film in the Phase 3 cinematic universe.
The film was directed by Anthony and Joe Russo and written by Christopher Marcus and Steven McFeeley.
The plot of the film is to bring people who have been snapped back to their former glory by searching for gems in the past, while the main character is led by Robert Downey Jr. as Tony S. Stark / Iron Man has a very prominent role and it's impressively well-acted. On the villain side, Josh Brolin plays Thanos, a very smart villain. Overall, I liked the storyline of this movie, the story of the journey while getting back the gems was fun and very addictive. As for the end of the story, it was very intense and impressive. And it's a bit sad, but this movie is a good start to the storyline of Phase 4. I was expecting Marvel to do well with the script, the CG settings, the sound, and it didn't disappoint really. All the actors did a great job. Until arriving here, the impression that everyone has been together for a long time until the end will become a beautiful new beginning, although very sad because of an unexpected ending and relationship. It shows the friendship that the characters have to each other that makes the audience feel the same way. Feel connected to the characters equally, including me.

This movie is a really good movie for me, but it might have been a little confusing on the intro for those who didn't watch the previous episode, it would have been nice to have a little bit of a reversal. But that doesn't make the movie any less fun.
    In this movie, we will meet the most exciting and epic battle in the Marvel Universe that we may not have seen in any other movie because of the fight against the eternal villains, Thanos, who has already possessed Infinity Gallet with all colors of gems, made him very powerful and made the all of the Avengers join in the fight. After all, it feels bent that the main character like Iron Man has to give up his life, and it's a scene that brings tears to my eyes.
   Avenger: Endgame, even though it's the end, I think it's the most perfect ending. Since protecting others requires sacrificing something or even someone's life to keep all the people on this planet alive, that's what we appreciate call them 'hero'.
   From the previous episode I watched, Avenger: Civil War, I felt that episode was really dreary and compared to this episode, making it clear that Marvel has evolved even more, whether it's a story walk that makes more sense, the effects are made me goosebump and think that it would cost more than a billion dollars. It likes Endgame is the best episode for all Avenger movies I've seen.
   Compared to movies and cartoons, I still feel that the movie itself is still not as detailed as it is in comic books, probably because with a few hours to screen and many books that can be released, it has to be partially dissolved.
   In the end, I'd like to conclude that it's a movie that's worth watching for once, but if you don't like such fantasy action movies, I wouldn't recommend it to you since it makes you feel dizzy and not fun at all, but for the fantasy action movie disciples, I recommend it to you all

Avengers: Endgame was a great way to end this ambitious movie project, which spanned 10 years with 22 superhero movies. It was an epic culmination that satisfied millions of fans worldwide. Because of the enormous success of Avengers: Infinity War, I wondered if this second part could top it. And to my amazement, it did that and even exceeded my expectations. It was even more epic and tragic than its predecessor. As expected, it had excellent special effects, great casting and acting. Well-distributed character spotlights. The plot wasn't perfect, but the overall grandiosity and intensity more than made up for it. There's a few fan service scenes that made the audience cheer. There's enough suspenseful battle scenes to keep you at the edge of your seat. Although some scenarios were predictable, there were a couple of scenes that still caught me by surprise: heroic sacrifices that will shock you. Disney/Marvel has succeeded in blowing us away, capturing our hearts, and giving us beloved characters that we will remember for a long time. Endgame made us realize that superheroes can be human too: they can feel love, be hurt and grieve. This epic conclusion will remain in our hearts because it inspires us and makes us believe that there can be hope even in the bleakest situations. It's no surprise that Avengers: Endgame has become  one of the highest-grossing films of all time.

This movie felt as an emotional rollercoaster, since it put an end to so many different stories that were presented to us on previous films, it was brilliantly achieved, as every other Anthony and Joe Russo movie. However I think is far from perfect, specially since there are some plotholes, the one that bothered me the most is that 2014's Nebula was able to bring Thanos and his army to the present despite the fact she only had one Pym particle. Let's be honest here, the only reason Thanos was brought to the heroes present was to do some fan service and finally see The Avengers kicking his ass, but the way he was brought was really stupid, Nebula tinkered with the transporter software and was able to bring all that people to another age, why? In this case main timeline's Nebula had to be able to do that too and she didn't even collaborated when building the machine...

I'm not sure what the fascination is with people who desire to be so 'edgy' that they can shave their face with their bare hands...but looking at some of the 1/10 reviews, it's a common fascination.

Some have fixated on 'plot holes' as a result of the time travel elements of the movie...its TIME TRAVEL. It's literally impossible to make a movie containing that topic and not be left with questions, since you can always interpret cause and effect/paradox elements of a time travel movie.

This film is actually peak marvel perfection. I review a film on how well it keeps me enthralled by asking myself how many times I thought about having a cigarette during a movie.

Now I rarely actually leave for one but if I'm thinking about it, im not fully engrossed.

Endgame made me forget I even smoked for its entire 3hr runtime (the added runtime making it even more challenging to acchieve). I cant possibly rate higher.

When I finally got outside I would describe the cigarette I had as less the feeding of a habit; and more as post coital.

Even as the darker film of the franchise they still bring some humor and avoid going full 'DC Dark'; and you still genuinely root for the characters, terrified for their possible fates.

The third act is nothing short of absolutely epic and my advice would be to be mindful of your surroundings...as the person next to you is at risk of damage on the several occasions where you can (and will) punch the air.

And if you dont have tears in your eyes towards the end, then you are the person the snap deserved to get.

A satisfying conclusion to the infinity saga and closure for two MCU heavyweights.
Tony has a compelling emotional journey and I would not accept any other ending for the godfather of this saga, fantastic work by both Downey and the writers.
Steve has a good conclusion but his journey there did feel somewhat forced with Peggy being shoe horned in to remind the audience that Steve still cares and yearns for the simple life.
I remain conflicted about Thor, his journey from Ragnarok to Infinity War is some of the most compelling character work in the MCU. Endgame attempts to carry this on but instead fills the Thor scenes with too much humour for me to remain immersed in his story.
Black Widows ending is quite underwhelming as her character has had little to do of significance since "Age of Ultron", also that tussle with Hawkeye feels comically misplaced. Renner is brilliant in the opening scene conveying the sense of loss and confusion experienced by a normal family.
The second act feels the need to move very quickly with the usual MCU humour sprinkled in far too much for my liking. The "comedy" scenes feel like the Russos reverted back to their "Community" or "Arrested Development" days too much for my liking.
The third act brings out the child in all of us and serves as one of the best thirds acts in MCU history.
I went into "Endgame" wanting an emotional conclusion to the stories of our OG Avengers and in some ways I got that.

Talk about a film living up to the hype.  This movie wrapped up over a decade of marvel storylines in a distinctly satisfying and emotionally cutting way.  I've seen this film over a dozen times since it was released in April of 2019 and I still end up in tears by it's conclusion.  Fluid character archs, abundant humor, crazy-intense action scenes, well placed callbacks, a gripping storyline and one HELL of a [maybe predicatble] ending... this movie simply had it all.  It's a rare thing where I am able to watch something more than once and enjoy it as much as I did the first time.  This is one of those rare gems.  I saw it twice in the theater and many more times at home with my own kids who are quickly becoming huge Marvel fans.  I caught my 14 year old son crying at the end of this one and honestly didn't blame him because, once again, I was fighting back my own tears.  A great film and an epic story that I will remain emotionally invested in for the rest of my life.  Well.  Done.

The definition of an absolutely perfect 10/10 film. Avengers Endgame is an expertly crafted clear and concise 3 act storyline; act 1 - a character study on how the Avengers deal with grief after the tragedy of half the population being eliminated by Thanos and their first true loss, act 2 - a fitting conclusion to all of the original 6's character arcs by means of time travel in which the avengers re-encounter parts of their pasts that previously caused them trouble and come to terms with them, influencing their actions throughout the final act, while also creating a thoroughly entertaining (and nostalgia boosted) journey for both die hard fans of the MCU and new fans, revising some of the MCU's best moments while also acting as an antithesis for Thanos' own journey to collect the infinity stones in Avengers Infinity War. And finally, act 3 - The best action sequence and all out war featured in any film, truly capable of captivating the audience in every rewatch, balancing a great amount of personal character driven moments for a wide variety of characters, heart pumping action, emotional moments and gratifying fan service moments done right that only amplify the amount of hype filled in scenes (The big 3 vs Thanos, Cap wielding Mjolnir, Portals, Avengers Assemble, the Armies charging together, Activate Instant Kill, Wanda vs Thanos, Iron Man's snap, etc…)

I got a chance to see this movie on first day first show in Pune, India. It was one of the most amazing moments in my life. The theatre was literally alive, all of us felt the grieve when Natasha died or Tony, all of us felt the joy of Cap lifting the Mjolnir for the  1st time and the end-credit signature sequence of the OG cast was on the next level. The cinematography of the movie was the best in all sense, and every time I watch this movie on my TV or anywhere I live those moments and its a bliss....

Avengers endgame is the perfect way to cap off the infinity saga within the MCU. Not only does it bring every character into its story but we also say goodbye to heroes that have been around since day 1 of the MCU. 5 stars

Avengers Endgame is the perfect conclusion to the Marvel Cinematic Universe. If it were the final movie in the entire series I would be very content with it, but it does setup a different world we will come to see in the future. As a fan of the comics the movies are based on, and a huge fan of the Marvel Cinematic Universe as a whole this movie was made with people like me in mind and I loved it. It brought emotion, laughs, and plenty of references and moments I have been wanting to see. For people who haven't seen a Marvel movie before this one, don't start here. This is not a movie for the average moviegoer to see without any background information and it will be incredibly boring, and you will be lost the entire time. For everyone else though, see this movie, enjoy it, and possibly even see it again. This is by far one of my favorite films in the Marvel Cinematic Universe and has plenty of scenes I will be watching again and again when it releases on Blu-ray.

The final movie of the Infinity Saga is the best cinecomic I've ever seen. It manages to culminate the saga with a movie full of heart and love for the original avengers. First act somehow unexpected, which gives a great idea of the ​​pain that persists through the world after 5 years. The second act is a love letter to the marvelous first adventure of the Marvel Cinematic Universe that lasted 11 years, full of quotes more or less explicit. Breathtaking third act that left me speechless every minute more, leading to the ending that is bittersweet and one of the most beautiful I've ever seen for a film saga. The characters complete 11 years of evolution in a sublime way, Stark and Rogers above all.
This and much more is the pearl of the Russo brothers. Simply in my top 3 of the movies I've ever seen.

A fine film that, in my eyes, feels very overrated. The comedy feels more forced, the story is just constant fan-service, and the final fight scene feels more cringe than epic due to the goofiness of some of the choices they made (ie all the Avengers running in a line). While the beginning and ending was admittedly great, and the acting is still as good as ever, "Avengers: Endgame" just fails to hold a light to some of the far better installments in the MCU. While I still found the film to be mostly enjoyable, I was able to find enough glaring flaws during my rewatch to bring the score down.

After much thought I have come to the conclusion that this is my Favorite Movie of All Time. It's 3 hours long, and it's all worth it. There's so much to talk about this film whether it's the drama between Cap and his final fight, Tony and coming to peace with his father, or Thor realizing that it's him that makes the lighting and not the lightning that makes him. The action is the best it's ever been, the CGI is world class as always, and the performances from the entire ensemble cast is as good as it'll ever be. Is it a perfect film? Heck no, but it's as close to perfect as you could ever get, and it comes pretty damn close. Avenger's Endgame broke the box office record and deservingly so, it's a film that cemented the MCUs legacy forever, and showed the world that superhero movies are "more than just a shield."

This film was everything I wanted it to be. It truly was the culmination of every character in the MCU coming together for one epic final ‘hurrah'. The premise of time-travel does get muddled a bit though, especially at the end, however the Russo Brothers explained this in a recent interview:

"Both Ancient One and Hulk were right. You can't change the future by simply going back to past. But it's possible to create a different alternate future. It's not butterfly effect. Every decision you made in the past could potentially create a new timeline. For example, the old Cap at the end movie, he lived his married life in a different universe from the main one. He had to make another jump back to the main universe at the end to give the shield to Sam."

This explanation plus the re-watch factor bumped this film up on the list. It truly is the epic finale that we have been waiting for. If Disney decided, they could easily end the MCU on this note. (Side note: They didn't and I'm grateful).

An Action Full Movie that Discards Itself from Real Cinema

As big, lasting fan of Marvel, I had trouble enjoying this long-waited finale at the fullest. After being left lost and confused on the event of Infinity War, we had to wait for a year to fully understand what was going to happen, and few months to start getting ideas with the small, lying, teasers. Yes, I say « lying » teasers, because today, most of Marvel's trailers provide false scenes that either make you hope or bewilder you (true MCU fans know what I'm talking about). Once more trailers were released and more information given, I was even more hyped. But when I sat at the theatre, watched the adventurous story unwrap, I started noticing how flawed and holed the narrative was. The first 5 minutes are amazing, I won't lie. But then, the story turns into this sad and forced comedy where we see a feeble Hulk dabbing, a depressive Thor that indulge his friends to play Fortnite, Tony being a jerk as always - even though he has a daughter, which I thought would have changed his stubbornness - and of course, the most annoying character of all time, a greedy overpowered woman named Captain Marvel. Then, we have the chance to understand how are they going to retrieve the stones in the past, and when it could explain it a very easy explanation, Hulk gives us the most complicated explanation about time-travel I have ever heard (you need to see the movie to understand this part). Then as the story goes on, we have a bit of action, a crying Thor (again), a great teamwork between Tony and Steve, a sad event with Natasha's sacrifice, and then once all stones are recovered, we jump immediately towards the nano-gauntlet getting the stones attached to it. We have no idea how Tony built it, how much time has passed, what is this new Thanos doing... nothing. Leaving a massive hole in the story (just like the ending).

But I prefer talking about the real issue of this movie - which isn't the massive CGI content that really is a significant reason why this movie discards itself from real cinema - which is the final battle. That battle can appear epic, for someone who only crave action and lasers and people dying from team-working heroes. But if you pay close attention to that moment, the battle doesn't make any sense at all. At any moment, they could just shred Thanos - like late arriving Captain Marvel shredded his ship in the blink of an eye. They are so many heroes, all together, strength attached, powers combined, and none decides to think « let's take him all together ». No, instead everybody just prefer attacking the meaningless troops that other characters like Wong, or the Wakanda's army can take care of. It's ridiculous. I know, the directors need to build tension and really focus the main characters's mindsets when it comes to fight - and of course, the actors's contracts that determine if someone will die or not. But that battle was straight up messed up. You're telling me, that in 14 million possibilities, no one sliced up Thanos's arm? The whole movie got destabilised because of Dr. Stranger's line saying they only won one battle. Yes, it creates tension and a very unpredictable story, but it lacks of sense.

Eventually, Marvel is no longer supposed to make sense. Now, it's just action, bad writing, and all about the actor's contracts.

Avengers: Endgame is a league of its own, and is my second favorite MCU movie. This movie, which marked the grand culmination of the MCU and the Infinity Saga, is a work of art that is probably a once in a decade occurrence. Endgame is a long movie, and rightfully so since it had a lot to do in that runtime. What's beautiful about the film though is that it manages to do all of that perfectly while delivering a lot of fan service moments and callbacks. Endgame is filled with references to previous MCU installments, but works them into the story beautifully so that the movie doesn't feel like it was made only for fan service. The filmmakers understood that they needed to progress the MCU and reach the conclusion of the Avengers conflict with Thanos at the same time as wanting to remind us of some notable moments from previous movies. From it's opening scene to its conclusion, Endgame is an emotional rollercoaster that grips you and never lets you go. There are funny moments, sad moments, happy moments and pretty much every kind of moment you can think of. Certain characters are given fantastic moments to shine and go through amazing arcs that show us how much they've changed since we first met them, and we get to see sides of them that we haven't seen before; certain actors give probably their best performance as their character yet. Many of Marvel's casting choices paid off immensely in this movie. The action is unbelievable and gives us an idea of what Marvel is capable of with fight sequences. The big battle of this movie gives the Wakanda one from Infinity War a run for its money. The script and directing are also phenomenal and help make the whole movie flow very smoothly. It's also nice to see certain actors reprise their roles from previous films, especially ones we haven't seen in a while. Endgame has a satisfying ending and great conclusion but still leaves plenty of room for storytelling and development, stuff we've seen recently with Disney+ shows. Thanos remains an intimidating villain in this movie and shows just how smart and powerful he can be when he needs to, giving another uncommon example of when a villain is allowed to reprise their role. There are times in Endgame where the continuity is questionable, but those times aren't very disruptive and are completely overshadowed by the good moments in the movie. At the end of the day, Endgame is a movie about failure and how it can impact people differently, but also about what it means to be a team and what you can achieve with teamwork and unity. Avengers: Endgame is the probably the best Avengers movie so far and is a true masterpiece on every front imaginable.

I almost cried after watching this movie at 12am when it came out. But for all the wrong reasons. Whilst this movie delivers the perfect character moments for Tony and Steve, it does so at the sake of the Marvel Cinematic Universe's Finale. Utter disappointment.

The plot is lazy and is relying on some random things to happen. Like the whole plot wouldn't happen if some random rat didn't press the right button at the right time. Or Thanos would have never known what's going on if Nebula went to get another stone or turned off her "wifi". Or what if the vision that Thanos saw, was just some random moment when Nebula is just walking a hallway. Still, the biggest issue is time travel. How it works and how you could just bring anyone from death. Why didn't they figure out how to make more Pym particles or get more from a different timeline in the first place. Tony Stark figured out the whole time travel thing in like one day so I cant see why that's so impossible. And in the end, they will have to get more of those particles. Also couldn't they just go back like an hour or day before Black Widow died and bring her back from dead? The explanation is this is not possible because it'll split timelines, but does it even matter because in the end there is a timeline without Thanos, his army, Nebula and Gamora. And couldn't they just do the same thing to Tony Stark or couldn't Doctor Strange just use the time stone to bring him from death? Tony wouldn't even have to die if Captain Marvel just flew away with the clove after she destroyed Thanos' ship. Why didn't she flew through Thanos in the first place as she did through his ship? Picking the time when all three stones were in New York doesn't make any sense. There are multiple points in time when they were sitting in some random lab or just on a table. The list goes on and on, but I'll end it here. Overall this movie was just fan service and isn't nearly that good as it's praised to be.

Did we really ask for this movie or do people watch it becasue it's all that's available? 
Also, I don't get the need to cast Robert Downy Jr as the lead. And putting him next to others with twice the star power isn't doing him any favors. ...He comes across like a regional manager.  Someone you have to show respect to, but has little to no personal currency.  His work here is done.

Avengers fans, assemble, for the ultimate Marvel movie that feels like a fanfic in all the right ways. For a three hour movie, it's insanely engaging, I only check my watch so I can time the consumption of my soda so I don't have to use the bathroom. In the context of the story, the plot makes sense. Upon this viewing, I thought of a tiny little hole when Nebula was able to bring back Thanos and his forces despite the finite Pym particles, but then I realized, he could have had time to reverse engineer the one our Nebula had before sending his Nebula back in her place, because time travel. The characters are so well balanced, and given the right send-offs and moving on to the next part of their journey. I love these characters 3000, and this being the sixth time I sat down and watched this movie beginning to end, I still broke down and cried when Tony gave his life for the universe. Combined with great visual effects, music, and a good balance of the usual Marvel tone with a more serious edge appropriate for the story, Endgame is the perfect way to send off some characters, and propel others to Phase 4.

Of all things I expected, a rat saving the universe was not part of it. After the snap, half the universe's population died, causing the avengers to lose all hope. Then when all seemed hopeless, Ant-Man emerged from the depths of the recently discovered quantum realm to open the door to the path of hope, justice, and closure. 

Just that moment alone made my day, but I didn't know at the time that I was in for a treat. The movie was surprisingly long, but in the end, it was worth it. The storyline for it was inspired by the comics, but once you see it, you look at it as if it's a whole other story. To watch all the avengers, new or old, coming together to fight was simply splendid. And the masterpiece of writing that it is, the movie was foreshadowed and built up so much for the last 11 years. It reflected the worst fears of avengers coming true, but despite the petrifying sight, they didn't back down.

 Although it did have a couple of plotholes, but downgrading a movie just because of a couple of plotholes is not the start of a good movie experience. Moreover, the characters made up for it. Captain America is a man we can all look up to. His character development was just phenomenal. The same can be said for Thor, the way he took the snap was disappointing to some people, but I think it reflects his character beautifully. Although what I didn't expect was clint's response to the situation. Being said that, seeing him back in action just brightened up the movie. And how can I not mention the MVP, iron man. Iron man, the genius, billionaire, playboy, philanthropist, was the most well-written character I had seen for a long time. He opened up a gate for the next generation to take the lead. And the star of the next-gen, Spiderman, not only won the heart of iron man, but he also became a fan favorite with just a couple of scenes. And the one character that made the movie what it is today, Thanos. Thanos is a character who works for the greater good and will sacrifice anything to achieve that. The thing that makes the movie so good is that he is a relatable villain. That brings out the sense of superiority in Thanos when compared to other antagonists.

Any movie is incomplete without the fan-requested scenes or a sacrifice that will shake the fans to their very soul. This movie had it all. Some people hate to say goodbye, and that's why it's harder for some people than others. And to relieve their feelings, they end up hating on the movie but trust the millions of good reviews on it; it's because the movie just brings a wave of sadness. One thing that does help cope with the over-flowing sorrow is the film's pure and brilliantly designed structure. The structure brings out this incredible sensation that can be described as nothing but epicness. You are on the edge of your seat all the time, and when the movie ends, you find your butt sore with all the pressure.

This movie was the perfect ending not just to phase 3 of the MCU but also to the old style and vibe. Because now the reins of the world are in the young heroes' hands. This movie showed us that the 11 years of waiting were worth it. I don't usually say this, but if it became available, I would watch it because it makes my hair stand just by seeing the beauty that has been laid in such an elegant manner.

3h needs more story telling. (With Infinity war, it's more than 5h for approximately 10 min story telling). Fights were just coming and coming, a long movie need some pause or it becomes boring. Marvel was OP, and Wanda too, but Stark's intelligence, crafting a gauntlet that auto-transfers the Infinity Stones, learning from their struggles on Titan, freakin' won the battle. EPIC. Just EPIC!

I'm not interested in reading Marvel comics at all. There are some like Deadpool and Spider-Man which I love to take a look occasionally, and I have every single Black Panther comic on my Comixology (although I have only read one of them), but other than that I have absolutely no attachment to any other Marvel superhero. And yet when I watched Avengers: Endgame, I could actually feel like this is something of my dream coming true. This is something I really needed and because of this I can say I have really seen histroy getting created in comic book movies.

The CGI of this movie is absolutely intense. Every nerd's dream is to see a cast assembly of their favourite franchise characters on the big screen played by actors in live action, filled with CGI. And this movie absolutely does it. This happening in the first two Avengers movies or Josstice League didn't feel too intense since there weren't many characters, but over here there are tons of them. And that made it look really badass.

We also get to revisit all the old MCU movies and have the nostalgia of those scenes. There is an emotional scene of Tony meeting his father, but most of them are funny like Hulk smashing the cars and Starlord singing Come Get Your Love from the opening scene of Guardians of the Galaxy. The fight scene between the two Captain Americas and Nebulas was decent, but the fact that they actually chose to add them when they could have gotten away really seems nice.

And then finally we have what we waited for in the last 3 hours. Iron Man, Captain America and Thor come together to fight Thanos. Thor looks so cool when he has lightning in his eyes. The fight scene of all three of them together against Thanos looked so well choreographed without any jump cuts, it didn't even feel like an MCU movie. And finally when all the portals open, Captain America finally says the fabled "Avengers Assemble" that we all had been waiting for to hear in the last 7 years.

Though there are many things about this movie that I didn't like at all. First of all, Black Widow's death. I really hate Black Widow. She seems to have some sort of a plot armour around her. Throughout the entire MCU I never saw her getting beaten even once. And she fights every cool looking bad guy with 1000 jump cuts. I had heard about her death being in this movie, so I was really excited to see her finally get whooped. But even then she died BY BEATING Hawkeye. She doesn't even have the decency to take a beating. Sorry Black Widow, I think I'm never gonna like you.

My next problem comes with Ant-Man's return. A mouse? Seriously? I get MCU is supposed to be a family movie franchise but this went a little too far. It could have been something better, like Scott finding something inside the quantum field that allows him to control space and time which could later be used to gather the Infinity Stones. Then I also have a problem with the Thanos army attacking the Avengers HQ. They have such heavy weapons, and they can't even make past a force field before Hulk uses the Infinity Gauntlet? And finally my problem comes with that all-female scene. It was so cringy! I don't know much if people probably like such scenes, but why was it needed at all? It's not like anyone was looking forward to it. With all that said, I have no other problem with this movie.

In my opinion Avengers: Endgame should have been the last movie of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Making more movies completely undermines the point of this movie. It is supposed to be a culmination of everything that has ever happened throughout the franchise. Now making more movies at this point is just blatant cash grabbing. I really hope that Disney decides to start Phase 4 from scratch, since it's becoming hard to keep track of all the MCU movies at this point.

Would rate it lower if I could....absolutely sucked....and had me thinking omg seriously is this what we've waited for all these years through all the movies for it to end this horribly....They made jokes out of both Thor and The Hulk characters, then they can manage to screw up Captain America's character by implying he would willingly go back and change history and in fact killing a few people that should be alive because his old flame had married and had kids and not to him....and they manage to kill off a bad ass character (cough Black Widow)  that is the only character that they can't bring back to life even though everyone else gets brought back or is magically okay again because they're messing with time....and then if that's not enough to ruin the ending they kill off Iron man as well......THIS MOVIE SUCKED!!!

It's a fun movie. That's all it really has going for it. I felt the writers wrote themselves into a corner with Infinity War and had no clue where to go next. The movie relies on fan service, without it it's confusing and eh to people who don't understand MCU lore. With that said: there is TOO MUCH fan service. Fan service is great to use, but when there is too much fan service it isn't great. There are some plot holes too, Civil War built up how Captain America and his friends are criminals then the concept is thrown out in this movie. They're pardoned for no other reason than to drive the plot. And the time travel, don't get me started. Infinity War had breathtaking, tense, and fantastic battles. Endgame had battles where two big armies ran at each other. I don't get why Okoye was marketed so much when she gets literally two minutes of screen time. On the poster, she is bigger than Nebula who has wayyyyy more relevance to the plot overall. Black Panther fading away at the end of Infinity War prepared itself truly to be great character development for Okoye, only two scenes were needed for her but nope.

Sort of like a copy my homework but make it different. And though it may seem that Marvel is prevailing I have to note the marvel formula is becoming a little bland for me. The edgy gritty feel of DC films keep you more immersed not too mention their complex storylines still leave many for debate proving it's superiority. 🎥 NON-SPOILER REVIEW OF AVENGERS: ENDGAME

How can I possibly explain the feeling I had after I saw the film. I was shooketh. Even in my wildest nerdest wet dreams I couldn't have imagined Endgame being this good. And Yet it was. Now, how can I talk about this film without TALKING about this film? Okay, let me just give my opinion of this film. Simply put; this is the greatest MCU film (to date) and that's saying a lot considering the classic MCU films that have come before it. This film packed an incredibly deep and emotional captivating story, filled with heart, pathos, and unmitigated joy. 

This film is built on the foundation from twenty-one other films; that could not have happened without each of them. Marvel Studios head Kevin Feige along with the Russo Brothers have crafted the most satisfying wrap up to eleven years of Marvel films. Wow. What an accomplishment this film is. This run of movies is something that never been done in Hollywood history. 

Okay about the film, it is so unexpected. I mean I did not know where this film was going to go before I watched it. The trailers gave you almost nothing as far as plot, asides from the few things I assumed would happen; and even then a lot of things happen that I never thought they would do. At the end of Infinity War, the world is in shambles. Our remaining Avengers are dealing with something they have never dealt with before; lost. They are defeated. They are desperate and there is a sense of dread you never seen in these characters before. They have to figure out a way to get Thanos or live with the aftermath of their defeat. 

What makes the MCU films so good is despite their superhuman powers and otherworldly origins at the end of the day they're human. They have emotions. They're in pain and because you've been so invested for years with them you feel it too. They feel real and you care about what happens to them. I cannot stress enough how important that it is, that YOU the audience care about these people. So when they are sitting around having talks with each other you are just as invested and entertained by their conversation as you are by watching them punch and blast somebody. 

And you know what? Because you care about these characters so much (the audience) is rewarded with fan services as they take you down memory lane and give you another look at the moments you loved and give new context to them. The writers of this Avengers Endgame Stephen McFeely and Christopher Markus do not get enough credit but they are geniuses. They know how to tug on your heart strings and make you laugh all within the same scene seamlessly.     

As for the ending- the final battle is such a tremendous triumph that has NEVER been done before; above and beyond anything ever done in a comic book movie before. You got to understand I grew up reading Marvel Comic Books since I was a small child, I know these characters and the storylines most of these films are drawn from, and I have never seen ANYTHING like this on screen before. There were moments where I yelled at the screen, clapped my hands, cheered, and geeked the f#%@K out at what I saw on screen. The things you waited eleven years to see happen, happened. And things you never thought you would see happen. And the thing you didn't know you wanted to see happen, happened. You will experience a gambit of emotions in the final hour that you never had before. 

The ending of Endgame puts a bow on everything that has happened in the MCU to this point and also opens the door to the future of the MCU that I have no doubt will be just as fantastic. What a time to be alive and a comic book fan. 

• Robert Downey Jr. as Tony Stark / Iron Man: 
The leader and benefactor of the Avengers who is a self-described genius, billionaire, playboy, and philanthropist with electromechanical suits of armor of his own making. According to directors Joe and Anthony Russo, Downey was the only actor to have read the entire screenplay for the film. 

• Chris Evans as Steve Rogers / Captain America: 
A fugitive superhero and leader of a fugitive faction of Avengers. A World War II veteran, he was enhanced to the peak of human physicality by an experimental serum and frozen in suspended animation before waking up in the modern world.

• Mark Ruffalo as Bruce Banner / Hulk: 
An Avenger and a genius scientist who, because of exposure to gamma radiation, transforms into a monster when enraged or agitated. 

•  Chris Hemsworth as Thor: 
An Avenger and the king of Asgard.

• Scarlett Johansson as Natasha Romanoff / Black Widow: A highly trained spy, a member of Rogers' faction of Avengers, and a former agent of S.H.I.E.L.D. 

• Jeremy Renner as Clint Barton / Hawkeye: 
A master archer who is a former Avenger and agent of S.H.I.E.L.D. Barton has a new outfit in the film, visually similar to that of Ronin from the comics. 

• Don Cheadle as James "Rhodey" Rhodes / War Machine: A former officer in the U.S. Air Force and Avenger who operates the War Machine armor. 

• Paul Rudd as Scott Lang / Ant-Man: A former petty criminal who acquired a suit that allows him to shrink or grow in scale and increase in strength. 

•  Brie Larson as Carol Danvers / Captain Marvel: 
An ex-U.S. Air Force pilot whose DNA was altered during an accident, which imbues her with the powers of superhuman strength, energy projection, and flight.

•  Karen Gillan as Nebula: An adopted daughter of Thanos who was raised with Gamora as siblings. 

• Danai Gurira as Okoye: A Wakandan traditionalist from the Border Tribe, who is the head of the Dora Milaje, Wakanda's all-female special forces, and T'Challa's bodyguards.

Josh Brolin as Thanos: 
An intergalactic despot from Titan who collected the six Infinity Stones to inflict his will on all of reality.

This movie is the perfect culmination of the 21 preceding films. It is exactly what any Marvel fan could be looking for in an epic finale. From the sense of hopelessness up until Scott Lang arrives to the riveting moment when Cap lifts Mjolnir and our vanished heroes emerge from their portals, this movie engages with its audience like very few films have. The feeling of dread when Clint and Natasha are flying to Vormir ending with complete heart-break is certainly one of the saddest sequences in the MCU. The subtle references to the previous films throughout the movie is the ultimate treat for the MCU's loyal fans. Chances are everything that you love about the MCU is in this movie and very little of what you don't is not. "Avengers: Endgame" was the biggest movie event of the 2010s, and to say the least, it did not disappoint.

This movie will end every clue, be it from the goodbye of the characters who created this universe and who will inherit it. Whether it's the death of the Iron Man who gave his life to save the world or Captain America that has returned to the past and use life worthy until its old age. And in this part, the most important death without her could not have happened was Black Widow, who sacrificed his life for Soul Stone. This film has many emotions that arise. The mood was happy that the characters returned from Snap, the sad goodbye to the characters we love, it was 3 hours, a memorable screenplay, and a very tight mark. If those of you who already like Superhero and follow the Marvel Cinematic Universe, they will love and like it a lot. I went to see this movie in theaters 5 times and every time I watched it, I never got bored. Excited every time about the important scenes. "Avengers: Endgame" is the end of a 10 year build up of a story running through all previous MCU films. It is a wonderful surprise filled epic , bringing all surviving characters and super hero's together for the final battle to save not only our own but multiple Universes. This one film carefully juggles excitement, drama and humor with 
Brilliant visuals and a sense of intrigue. The use of previous MCU films dialogue and scenes bring something new and special to the experience. The loss of beloved Characters , that we have followed on a ten year journey, helps the film to send us on a roller coaster of emotions. A great film that deserves its current status as the biggest grossing film of all time.

Not all sequels needed to happen. There are simply too many famous people in this movie! I prefer the old Avengers movies, when the focus was on just one character. I don't like this crossover business. Like, what is a kid from Brooklyn (Spiderman) doing in space?! It's gone too far. I feel these movies are now too removed from reality. Half the sets are CGI for cripes sake. I miss the days of practical effects and good, simple performances, plus a maximum of 1-2 heroes per film. That being said, I do like a lot of the famous people in this film. Mary Kate Olsen was very refreshing to see acting again and I really will always love RDJ. Chris Evans is a welcome treat at any point. The rest are there, I guess, but the movie spends so little time on them you'd never know it. Overall, it's kind of fun, but no masterpiece or anything.

I am really sorry for giving this score. I am usually able to enjoy any action movie as long as it has good action sequences. But this movie has so many logical flaws it makes it hard to enjoy. How was this the only way the Avengers win (according to Doctor Strange)? Why didn't they just go back when Thor struck Thanos and had all infinity stones? Wouldn't that create a universe where the snap never happened and keep theirs with all the humans? Why didn't Doctor Strange return Tony back to life with the time stone? Because there are next to no regulations on time travel there are a million better ways to everyone back to life without so many casualties. And the scene where Thanos from the past find out about the avenger's plans feels so forced. The list goes on and on but these are not the only flaws. My other big complaint about it is the final battle. It could have redeemed the entire movie but it's good guys fighting bad guys with the sole purpose of defeating the bad guys and bad guys fighting good guys for the sake of defeating good guys. It totally lacks any tension. As a comparison the battle of Wakanda from Infinity War had the bad guys fight to get the mind stone and the good guys stalling for Shuri to have enough time to finish the surgery on Vision. It has a lot of good things as well and I don't think that these flaws make it unwatchable but so many other people praised all of the good things. Overall I do recommend watching it but it leaves so much to be desired and I feel that some minor changes could have made it so much more better.

'Avengers: Endgame' is all of what I expected/wanted and more. I got goosebumps twice throughout the (masterfully paced) 181 minute run time, I can't say many films have inflicted that on me! Love the ending and the way the Infinity Saga story wraps up.

The action is ultra thrilling, the score is fantastic and the effects remain great. I will say I don't think they nail the screen time for all involved outstandingly - that's not a negative, at all, it's just the fact that 'Captain America: Civil War' and 'Avengers: Infinity War' did it to an incredibly higher degree previously.

The cast are marvellous, pardon the pun. Robert Downey Jr. and Chris Evans remain superb and are still the most standout, though you also have the likes of Chris Hemsworth, Josh Brolin, Scarlett Johansson, Bradley Cooper and Mark Ruffalo - love the look of Hulk in this one, btw.

I've only become properly aware of all of the MCU in the last two weeks or so, yet this still gave me a memorable experience seeing this main story crescendo like this - I imagine it would've been quite the journey 'live' from ten years or so prior to the release of this.

Look forward to continuing with 'Spider-Man: Far From Home' and the end of Phase Three, and then - all things well - beyond.

AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA! This movie was amazing! I don't know what else to say. I do disagree with a few choices, and the beginning does drag on a bit, but the amazing parts are so amazing I don't care. I genuinely don't believe we'll ever get a more epic and cohesive cinematic universe than the MCU. It took Marvel over a decade to establish all the characters and set everything up. Infinity War and Endgame are the culmination of over a decade's worth of careful cinematic planning. The sheer scale of it... The nostalgia, too, because we grew up watching these movies. We've been watching these characters on our screens for years. We've seen them grow and develop. I honestly think we will never get a series of interconnected movies like this in our lifetime. Who could even do it? DC tried and it didn't really work out. They were behind and they rushed it. They have a couple of good movies, but not like Marvel. And there's also the superhero fatigue to keep in mind. Maybe Disney could do this with Star Wars. There are also the X-Men movies. But I digress... 

I've seen the entire Marvel Cinematic Universe multiple times. I love all of the movies. They're very good as a standalone. But they're even better when you take into account the shared universe element. I genuinely believe Avengers: Endgame is peak superhero genre. It's the apex. We will never get a more epic superhero movie than that in our lifetimes. Maybe Marvel will hard-reboot everything in like 50 years, who knows... This has been an incredible journey. And I know Marvel will keep making movies, but I think it can only go downhill from Endgame. I don't believe they can outdo the Infinity Stones and Thanos storyline and everything before that lead to it.

'Avengers: Endgame' is the pinnacle peak for all Marvel movies. After 11 years, 3 phases, and 22 movies, the MCU has successfully brought together all their superhero characters for what could be the best showdown in cinema, and have successfully concluded this massive Infinity saga in the most incredible, epic way possible. 
This movie goes in directions you would never have thought of, especially early on, just like how Marvel does best. It definitely needed to be three hours long in order to tie up everything from all the movies, and it does that so satisfyingly.
I am very privileged to have experienced this once-in-a-lifetime cinematic journey on the big screen from the very beginning, and I thank the entire cast, Marvel President Kevin Feige, directors Anthony and Joe Russo, all the people behind the camera, and lastly Stan Lee and Jack Kirby; without whom none of this would've been possible. I'll always be there on opening day to see what comes next in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
P.S. See it in IMAX if you can! It's worth the extra money.

Massive in scale and emotional Impact, Endgame doesn't miss a beat with its 180 minute runtime, with every character having their time to shine, while them looking back on the past to heal any broken wounds. The third act was a-lot of fan service, but felt paid off by the build up thanks to the past 10 years of having characters stories tied into each other. Satisfied and joyful with how they ending the first storyline and how they tired up phase 4. A massive congratulations to Joe and Anthony Russo, they have pulled off an amazing film and will go down as a cinematic event that everyone should see, not by the action or comedy (even though they were amazing to have), but how characters and stories tie in with each other and create a bigger picture.

I think any viewer, buying a ticket for this film, is aware of what he expects to see on the screen. Recently, the film industry has been criticized for the abundance of projects of a purely entertaining nature, including the "Avengers". However, if you look closely - it turns out that there is not so much really good and quality entertainment cinema. Some films are boring, some are bluntly stupid; and, for the most part, it turns out that "entertainment" can be called only a few luxuriously shot scenes, and at other times the viewer is forced to entertain himself with popcorn and cold cola. So the "Avengers" is a completely different case.

Avengers Endgame is a gift, a gift for all fans who have followed this historic 12-year journey. This film is not just a film of heroes, but a film full of action, drama, moments of tension, hope and surprise. We can say that it is the greatest film in history. The film that made the entire planet wait for 1 year. The film that made the whole planet vibrate and cry in the cinema, as if it were a football stadium. We all had exciting and unforgettable moments in our lives when we were watching Avengers Endgame in the cinema. Who hasn't cried with the death of Iron Man, played by Robert Downey Jr., since 2008, with the movie Iron Man, the movie that started the biggest franchise in history? I don't know. Who was not moved by the death of the Black Widow, played by Scarlett Johansson, who sacrificed herself for the greater good, for the save the universe? I don't know either. Who didn't cry at the departure of Captain America, played beautifully by Chris Evans, who went back in time to be with his beloved? I have no idea. "Avengers Endgame" just has way too many plot holes in it to consider it a good movie. I admit, it was my dream as a geek to see all of these heroes united on a big screen 10 years ago, and the final battle is absolutely spectacular... BUT... Why did the whole team decide to do time travel after 5 years of what happened and not before? Why didn't the avengers just take the glove from Thanos when he already got it using time travel, rather then cutting his head off for the second time. Of course there would have been no movie, but I believe there might have been a way to made it different. Marvel loves time travel, and whereas DC explains it as something that Flash can naturally do, Marvel Comics do it in nearly every single one of their comics events, especially "Age of Ultron" and "Days of Future Past", in which wolverine did all the time travelling by himself. It just feels like a really fast paced ending. We didn't really get to feel the emotions of the characters and struggle with them, as they have lost their fellow comrades, all we have got is, "That's not how time travel works". There was no explanation to how Hulk got to control himself, how did Tony Stark get a baby in such a strange time and why. How did Thor get so fat and why, if he understands that he could not be worthy for the hammer he so desperately wants to handle again. Why is there no explanation to what will happen to these dimensions where the Avengers travelled to, taking all these artefacts? Our Thor took his Mjolnir, but Thor of that dimension would be forever doomed and will struggle in many future fights, most especially why did his mom allow another Thor to handle it? What will happen to these worlds without the infinity stones? At least in "Age of Ultron" comic it showed that the time travel can make consequences. But, besides it's many flaws, "Avengers: Endgame" is a good ending for most of the characters and could be entertaining enough to watch if you are a fan of the franchise, but not if you are a fan of movies overall.
