Avengers: Endgame es una obra maestra. Es una de las mejores películas de la historia. Tiene todo, ¡TODO! Acción, diversión, drama, romance. Todo.
Como Blockbuster, Avengers: Endgame es una película que no teme en aventurarse de una manera sutil y satisfactoria en terrenos más complejos y pantanosos, y hacer remembranza de hitos culturales modernos. De esa manera, nos encontramos con una recuperación del espejo de Tarkovsky, espejo roto y confuso, en un decidido pero dolido Capitán América al observar su propio trasero; un Tony Stark presa de la 'fosterkaneitis', no pudiendo hacer las paces con su propia existencia a pesar de la infinidad de recursos; una Viuda Negra levantando sus femeninos puños y clamando por un lugar de heroísmo y valentía que desde los orígenes de la civilización occidental estuvo siempre reservado a aquellos que pueden alardear de un falo, audacia cinematográfica que hasta el momento sólo podía disfrutarse en las producciones de un joven Cassavetes o la belga Akerman, pero que Marvel la extrapola al cine de masas; la crítica brutal y devastadora al narcisismo y a la apatía actuales (claramente inspirada por los movimientos filosóficos contemporáneos) de la mano de la actuación 'oscar worthy' de Mark Ruffalo como Hulk, cuya desconexión con la realidad es tanta que al perder a su amada, sólo puede atinar a revolear un banquito de plaza; una excelentísima, para nada barata y para nada forzada escena de empoderamiento femenino.
A pesar de todo lo anteriormente mencionado, Avengers: Endgame continúa en el trayecto de la grandeza homérica y de las ambiciones 'fitzcarraldeanas' y nos regala un momento único en la historia de la cinematografía mundial, y definitivamente de los mejores que hemos visto: La escena del pegaso. La osadía de Anthony y Joe Russo tras las cámaras y de las plumas de Markus y McFeely permiten al espectador disfrutar de un momento inigualable, completamente definitorio para el Universo Cinematográfico en su entereza; uno no puede más que agradecer a la mente visionaria y trascendental de Kevin Feige por habernos permitido presenciar este nivel de talento narrativo y fílmico, logrando cristalizar años y años de avance cultural en una escena extraordinaria. Quizás, pero un leve quizás, sólo se podría mejorar a esta película si cada personaje tuviera un pegaso, ya que ¿que no es el pegaso la representación de la capacidad imaginativa de las personas, que nos permiten volar desde la comodidad de una silla o con la compañía de un ser querido? ¿acaso no nos transporta este noble corcel mágico a esos momentos especiales, cálidos ingenuos y sencillos, de nuestra niñez?
¡Hurra por Avengers: Endgame, que es todo esto y mucho más! En pocas palabras, la mejor película de todos los tiempos.

There is a lot to be said for the sheer spectacle of Endgame with truly amazing scenes of a scale we have not seen before, but the heart of the film lies within its characters. Infinity War was about Thanos' journey with the MCU roster clocking in as nearly secondary characters in their own film which was a genius tactic of making him almost sympathetic and at the same time fully displaying his sheer force of will and commitment to his objective. Endgame now puts the spotlight back on our heroes and how they deal with the magnitude of events that have befallen them; they've lost despite giving everything they had.

This movie is the reminder of what cinema is supposed to be, not only a snobbery space for old film-makers to dictate what movies are but a feast for the eyes and the feelings, a piece of entertainment that keeps you invested not only in the plot but in every character in the story, granted, this movie on its own isn't so special but the fact of being the culmination of 12 years of storytelling makes it a great roller-coaster of feelings, following characters you've invested tie for a decade until their end, it feels like a farewell to an old friend. this film unlike most blockbusters, doesn't leaves the character development for the spectacle, it pulls and pushes the humanity of the characters for the audience to relate to them, as people. it's the encapsulation of what marvel comics was in its printed media putting the human in the super human side of the super hero ideal. a spectacle driven film in which the visual effects are rivalled by quiet moments of family, loss, sacrifice and humanity overall. a pace where you feel the loss of Thor's mother as a powerful scene, the anger of hawkeye's drive, and the desperation of the rest of the characters as powerful as the excitement of seeing all the characters on screen displaying their abilities on the final battle. it is not a masterpiece by itself but considering it part of the greatest cinematic universe on the big screen is a masterpiece that delivers the entertainment films are made for.

Hoy tuve la oportunidad de ver "Avengers: Endgame". Es increíble lo que los hermanos Russo y la compañía Marvel han hecho durante éstos últimos 11 años.
La película es toda una oda y un tributo a lo que nuestros superhéroes y nosotros junto con ellos hemos vivido en todo éste tiempo.
La película puede llegar a ser demasiado en algunos momentos, y algunas situaciones son explicadas de manera muy simple para que todo fluya pero, sin duda las 3 horas están más que justificadas.
Durante la película reí, lloré y sin duda…. Nadie está preparado para lo que van a ver. Todas las teorías o lo que creemos que va o no va a suceder no es nada comparado con lo que la película realmente es, una obra de arte dentro del género de superhéroes.
La última hora de la película es quizás lo más asombroso y maravilloso que se haya filmado hasta la fecha en cualquier película de éste género. Es la culminación de 11 años y 22 películas, todo un logro fílmico que cómo Nadia Comaneci, aterrizaron con un 10!

What is there to say that hasn't already been said? Endgame is the culmination of a movie series that's over a decade old. It's not without its flaws. Pacing is an issue and there are a couple of small timeline continuity errors. However, these issues do not take away from how immensely wonderful this movie is. There's a ton of emotion and the action-sequences are beyond epic. I don't think there will ever be a superhero movie like it, therefore, it deserves every star possible.
A brilliant way to end an incredible franchise.
They screwed up the Hulk.
An exceptionally satisfying (though slightly fan service-y) end to a massive chapter in not only Marvel films but film history, that manages to both have fun and an emotional center.

Ugh, this shows what you can get when you have ALL the money to do whatever you want to do.

Having an infinite budget creates a fantastic looking movie, undoubtable: great score, effects, even the performances were great, they even did intelligent Hulk (no sure WHY), the plot isn't terrible, just awkward.

It felt very "shoe horned", the director(s) clearly had very specific things they wanted to squeeze in this time around and got everyone of them on screen. There will be times where you're like, "Why is this happening now?" and there's your answer, because someone thought it looked cool on screen. My favorite being the "ultra feminist" moment when they isolated the ladies to one part of the battlefield...for some reason...and they all charged in together. Don't get me wrong and it was cool to see all the strong lady characters fight together (reminiscent of Age of Ultron's opening battle scene), it was just so FORCED that it calls it into question instead of just treating them like everyone else and coordinating the attacks.

This is another one where its like they let the writers of the Walking Dead take a shot: they pull a bunch of important scenes from the comics only to change everything, and when they ran out of ideas, they did it again.

Look, the movie is worth your time, it's definitely enjoyable on its own: I can't imagine anyone but real comic fans even getting the slightest bit upset about this one.

If you have followed the Marvel Universe closely, this will be a very epic ending, I personally recommend having seen the previous MCU movies before you see this one.
Good acting, great effects, and an unprecedented story.

Si has seguido de cerca el Universo de Marvel, este será un final muy épico, recomiendo en lo personal haber visto las películas anteriores del MCU antes ve ver esta.
Buena actuación, excelentes efectos, y una historia sin precedentes.

Literally the greatest series in cinematic history. I know Sci-Fi, I know Disney, but the cohesive performances of all the cast, directors, music, visual effects, and story line are unmatched. Love it 3000
Una obra de arte! sin precedentes

This is easily the biggest movie of the century so far. That doesn't mean its the best superhero movie, but Avengers: Endgame is the culmination of over 11 years of buildup and the ultimate payoff. It is currently the highest grossing film in existence, and it certainly earned it. Endgame is more than a movie, its a comic book event, that will likely be remembered for the ages. It will take a while before anyone can top this at such a grand scale. Endgame manages to pay off many great movies both in the movie and from the previous 21 movies. The best payoff was arguably Captain America summoning Mjolnir. In Avengers: Age of Ultron, everybody tried to lift Thor's hammer at a party, but most of them failed. When Cap tried to lift the hammer, he budged it and was able to lift it but chose not to. However, in Endgame, Cap finally summoned Thor's hammer and when that shot happened, the whole theater erupted. It was such an amazing moment. Endgame is also a counterpart to Infinity War in many ways. They showcase the same themes throughout both movies.  However, the best comparison between the two movies was the scenes on Vormir. In Infinity War, Thanos learns that in order to get the soul stone, he has to sacrifice something that he loves. The only person Thanos loves is his daughter, Gamora. Thanos does not even hesitate to sacrifice his own daughter, the only person he loves, in order to achieve his goal to wipe out half of all life in the universe. In contrast, when Hawkeye and Black Widow receive the same news, their reactions are almost the opposite. Neither of them are willing to let the other one sacrifice themselves to save everyone. Both Natasha and Clint are willing to make the sacrifice, but both don't want the other to do it. In fact, they even have a fight to see who would die. In the end, Black Widow ends up making the sacrifice in a death scene that most of us didn't expect. Infinity War shows a villain at his worst, while Endgame shows heroes at their best. Endgame also did a perfect job concluding the character arcs of the characters that we've known and loved for up to over a decade, namely those of Black Widow, Captain America, and Iron Man. Black Widow has spent her whole life fighting, lying, and even killing for evil organizations. She tries to help people because she feels that she needs to redeem herself. In The Avengers, she said "I've got red in my ledger, and I'd like to wipe it out." She thought by working for SHIELD, she was redeeming herself, but then we find out that SHIELD was really HYDRA. In The Winter Soldier, Black Widow says: "I thought I knew who's lies I was telling, but I guess I just traded in the KGB for HYDRA." After the snap, Natasha has spent the last 5 years doing everything to try to bring everyone that she lost back. After Infinity War, the defeat had hit her personally. She never had any family but the Avengers, so she had nothing else to do but continue the job. Black Widow was the one that was never able to move on from the snap, because she had nothing else. She spent her whole time trying to continue to keep the world safe even in an post-apocalyptic era. Her sacrifice in Avengers: Endgame was a perfect conclusion. If they didn't get the stone, half the universe would stay dead, and everything she had done for the last 5 years would all be for nothing. Clint had a family, and if he died, he would never get to see them again. If she died, she would be dying FOR her family, to save it. For her, this was also the only way to redeem herself for her past actions by saving everyone. The relationship between Natasha and Clint is also handled perfectly. In The Avengers, Black Widow mentions that Hawkeye was sent to kill her, but he made a different call and saved her. Ever since she feels like she owes him. This is perfectly called back in Endgame, after Hawkeye has gone insane after his family was killed by Thanos, the other remaining Avengers don't want anything do with him and Rhodey even says that he shouldn't be found. Like Clint did for her many years before, she finds Clint and convinces him to help them. This time, Clint is the one that's dangerous, and Natasha is the one that has to save him from himself. So when they're both on the cliff in Endgame, there is a perfect callback when Clint thought that he deserved to die because of what he did over the last 5 years. Natasha responds saying that she doesn't judge people by their worst mistakes and Clint says that maybe she should. Natasha responds saying: "You didn't." These few lines sum up their entire relationship perfectly. Finally, she decides that it needs to be her to make the sacrifice so that Clint can get back to his family and half the universe comes back. By sacrificing herself, she finally paid her debt to Clint. He saved her life, and now she saved his. This was a perfect and well-thought out conclusion to Black Widow's arc. Next we have Captain America. Steve has always been a noble and selfless person. He always does what he knows is right, and sticks to his principles no matter what. Even if anyone and everyone is telling him do something wrong, he won't do it. Cap has been through plenty, and so for the last 5 years, hes been helping other people get over their grief. Cap has put his life on the line time after time to save other people, and still is not able to be happy. In the First Avenger, Captain America has to sacrifice himself by crashing a plane to save millions of lives. Because of this, he is not able to get that dance with Peggy Carter or the life he truly wanted. He ends up surviving by waking up 70 years later, but he sacrificed his happiness. In Age of Ultron, Tony said that he wanted to try having a normal life and a family and told Cap that he should try it one day. Cap said that the one who wanted that went in to the ice seventy years ago and someone different came out. In Endgame, when Cap goes to visit Tony Stark, he sees the family life he has with his wife and daughter. Cap didn't realize it, but its exactly what he wants. So at the end of the movie, Cap realizes that there is a way for him to have his life that he wants. He finally does something in his own self-interest and not to protect others. Cap goes back in time, returns the stones, and finally gets the dance that he's been wanting for over 75 years. It was a sweet ending, and it was earned. Finally, we have Iron Man. Tony Stark is arguably the central character of the MCU and he was the one who started everything with 2008's Iron Man. Tony starts off as a self-obsessed arrogant asshole who takes no accountability or responsibility for his actions. He doesn't care about all the horrible things his company has done or all the lives that have been taken because of him. However, his life changes forever after he was kidnapped by terrorists in a cave in Afghanistan. He realizes that his own weapons are being sold to terrorists, who use his weapons to take tens of thousands of lives. He and Ho Yinsen make a plan to escape, and Yinsen helps Tony build his first Iron Man suit. However, Yinsen dies helping Stark in the escape from the cave. As he died, he said the words that would change Tony's life forever: "Don't waste your life." For the first time in his life, Tony thanks someone else for helping him. After his escape, Tony realizes that he is responsible for his company selling those weapons to terrorists, and that it is his responsibility to stop this. First, Tony shuts down his weapons manufacturing division of his company. Then, he creates the Iron Man suit and destroys all of his weapons that the terrorists are using. This combination of his guilt for the lives hes destroyed and his responsibility to protect anyone else from being harmed are Tony's driving factors. His guilt only amplifies when in Avengers: Age of Ultron, when by trying to protect the world, he creates Ultron, who almost destroys the whole planet. Tony also has an internal conflict, in which he is unable to stop being Iron Man. This conflict was demonstrated in Iron Man 3 and at the end of Age of Ultron, where he retired and tried to stop being Iron Man. But, in Civil War, Tony admits to Cap that even though he knows he should stop being Iron Man, he doesn't want to, because he feels like all the bad things that have been happening in the world are his fault, and the weight of his guilt over all those years is still weighing down on him. In Age of Ultron, Tony had a vision of all the Avengers dead except for him and a massive alien army invading Earth. In this vision, Tony sees that they died because he couldn't do more to protect them. Tony does get the chance of becoming a father with Peter Parker. He recruits Peter in Civil War and takes him under his wing. Their relationship is demonstrated perfectly in Homecoming and Infinity War as they evolve from mentor and student to father and son. So during the snap in Infinity War, when Peter dies in Tony's arms, Tony feels like its his fault, because he couldn't protect him. After this, Tony thinks hes going to die drifting off into space, and he tries to send a message to Pepper telling her that he's sorry that they weren't able to start a family. After he is rescued however, he realizes that there's no going back and that the only way to protect the people he loves is to not be Iron Man. He and Pepper have a kid and happily live on a farm. Tony finally gets the perfect life he wanted. This is why when Captain America and the other Avengers come to him to ask for his help to reverse the snap, Tony refuses. The snap gave him the best 5 years of his life, and he was not willing to give that up in order to bring back half the universe. He is now responsible for protecting his family, and helping the Avengers will only harm his family. However, Tony stumbles across a picture of Peter Parker, who had died in his arms 5 years ago. He still feels responsible for Peter's death, and realizes that by not helping to save the universe, he was also abandoning his surrogate son and allowing him to stay dead. He remembers his guilt and feeling of responsibility, and knows that he has no choice but to help save everyone, even if it means that he has to give up everything. Pepper understands how he feels and allows him to do it, knowing that Tony won't be able to rest if he doesn't. During the time heist, Tony finally gets to talk to his father, who he's always had a rocky relationship with. It was only now, after he became a father that he understood some of the things his father had done, and that Howard would do anything for him. At the end of the final battle of Endgame, Tony realizes what he has to do. In Infinity War, Dr. Strange had told him that out of 14 million outcomes, they only won in one outcome. Just minutes ago, Strange also told Tony that if he told him what happened, it wouldn't happen. Now, Thanos was putting the gauntlet on and everyone else near him was knocked out. Tony finally realizes what the one outcome was and what he had to save everyone from dying again. 15 years ago, in Iron Man, after Pepper told him he was going to kill himself trying to save people, Tony said: "I shouldn't be alive, unless it was for a reason. I just finally know what I have to do." Now Tony knew the reason he was still alive. Tony Stark made the ultimate sacrifice and saved everyone in the end. With his final words, he said the same words that started it all: "I am Iron Man." Tony's arc came full circle here. It was sad, but very fulfilling and true to the character. After Logan's death in Logan (2017), I didn't think any superhero's death could be sadder. But Endgame proved me wrong, as I actually kinda cried at Iron Man's death. The funeral scene was a perfect tribute of the entire MCU cast of heroes paying tribute to the one who started it all and in the end, saved them all. And the cherry on top was Pepper's original gift to Tony from Iron Man on the wreath that said "Proof that Tony Stark has a heart." Endgame also took characters that were previously boring and uninteresting and turned them into compelling and interesting characters. The most improved player was Hawkeye. Hawkeye was not that interesting in any movie before (except maybe a bit in Age of Ultron) and wasn't even in Infinity War. But he was really good in Endgame. Hawkeye was the one grounded in reality and he was the one hit personally by the snap. While people like Captain America were grieved that they couldn't save the whole universe, Hawkeye was mad that he just couldn't save his own family. We see his rage, pain, and loss, and his interactions with most of the team, especially with Black Widow was often really powerful. I didn't at all care for Nebula in the Guardians movies and she wasn't there much in Infinity War. But now, she finally got her own arc. Nebula has to confront her past self, and decide to choose between who she was, and who she is. Her interactions with past Gamora and Past Nebula, especially now that she knows that Gamora did care about her, are really interesting, and her decision to save Gamora and kill her past self, albeit confusing how she doesn't die too, has started to feel like her defining moment. I have mixed opinions about Thor. He was much better in Ragnarok and Infinity War than he was in Endgame, but he wasn't. I thought the whole Thor being depressed was pretty good, and it seemed like the most logical thing that would happen after Infinity War, and Chris Hemsworth showcases his talent so well as one second he's laughing and making jokes and the next, he's sad and broken. The Thor and Rocket duo still works, but is handled much better in Infinity War. I also thought the redemption of Thor was a pretty good arc and the conversation with his mother was a great addition. But I don't like how his physique is used as a joke throughout the whole movie. It worked the first few times, but then it just got irritating. Also, Ragnarok and Infinity War showed his power growing stronger and stronger, and now hes just nerfed into oblivion in Endgame. I know it was necessary, or else he would've just soloed Thanos, but it still felt like a huge downgrade. Overall, Thor was handled pretty well. Kind of like Thor, I have mixed opinions on Hulk. I started by liking Professor Hulk, then not, liking it, and then it sort of grew on me. Of course, the problem is we wont see any true Hulk action, and I really wished they'd actually show us how Banner combined himself and Hulk. I did like his character overall though, and the scene where Professor Hulk snaps his fingers is awesome. Endgame also does a great job of showcasing how people go through grief. Black Widow is in denial and is still stuck in the past, trying to not believe that what happened in Infinity War happened and there's not much they can do about it. She is unable to move on because she has nothing else. Hawkeye is in anger. He saw what Thanos did to his family and has never gotten over it. After his family died, Hawkeye goes on an insane killing spree trying to make the world feel his pain. Hulk is trying to figure things out. He hasn't completely gone past the fact that he lost twice, but he's been trying to figure out what to do with himself after the fact. Hulk is trying to move on to other things to forget about his grief. One thing he did was to merge himself with Hulk to create Professor Hulk. Thor is in depression. He, more than anyone feels responsible for the trillions of people that died in Infinity War. He was the one that had a shot at killing Thanos, and has never forgiven himself for his decision out of pride to declare to Thanos that he, Thor killed him and fulfilled his brothers promise, instead of going for the head and killing Thanos straight away preventing all these deaths. Thor already lost his mother, his father, his sister, his home, half his people, his best friend, and his brother. Being responsible for the deaths of half of the universe was the last straw. On top of that, he also found out that there was no hope for him to undo his actions because Thanos destroyed the Infinity Stones, and Thor killed the Mad Titan in cold blood, chopping off his head two days late. Because of this, Thor goes completely wacko and spends his days playing Fortnite with Korg and Miek and drinking tons of beer. Tony is in acceptance. Tony has accepted what happened in Infinity War, and he has completely moved on. He now lives on a ranch with Pepper, and they have a young girl named Morgan. Tony is no longer still affected by his grief, and his life is now completely different. And finally, we have Steve. Steve isn't stuck in any of these stages, and he gets over his grief by helping others get over theirs. He's a grief counselor, as he's been through so much sadness even before Infinity War, that even though he may not be able to move on, he's able to help others get past their grief. Now I do have some issues with the movie. I do think the time travel is a bit confusing, especially with Nebula at several times, and I do think that the humor can be misplaced at times. But that's about it. And as for the latter of my issues, the humor isn't as misplaced as most humor in movies in general. In short, Avengers: Endgame can be divided into three parts, each about an hour each. The first hour is a character study, the second hour is a time heist, and the third hour is the final battle. Now we move on to the best part of the movie: the entire final battle. Wow! I have never seen anything as epic as this battle on screen before. The final battle in Endgame is filled with plenty of action, tons of amazing moments, and of course the most iconic scene in comic book movie history. The only part of the final battle that I didn't absolutely love or wasn't completely shaken by the sheer spectacularity of the battle was the forced in girlpower moment. I didn't hate it like many people do, and it didn't completely take me out of the movie, but I just thought it was way, way, way too convenient that all the female heroes were in one exact spot at the exact same time during such a massive battle and it feels like it was forced into the movie. We start off with an amazing fight that everyone has been waiting for. The Big Three, the trio of the the franchise are all back together, going against Thanos, the big bad of the entire MCU. Thanos's speech to the heroes was so intimidating and awesome: "You could not live with your own failure. Where did that bring you? Back to me." This Thanos is a step down from Infinity War Thanos, but it makes sense, considering that he saw that people would not be grateful to him for what he did, and is was a younger, more brash Thanos. Thanos is still a really threatening villain, and it somehow manages to up the stakes even higher than Infinity War. One, because we saw what happened in Infinity War, and we saw the massive effects it had everywhere. Two, because now, hes going to destroy the entire universe and recreate it. The action is awesome, and once again shows the chemistry and teamwork between the fighters, for example, when Thor uses his lightning to supercharge Iron Mans suit. But, the best part of this fight comes when Thanos is about to kill Thor, and then Mjolnir lifts off the ground and knocks Thanos at the head, and the hammer rebounds flying into the hands of Captain America! Cap did really well against Thanos, but Thanos still manages to get the upper hand. Cap is utterly defeated, with his shield broken and lying on the ground. Then Thanos reveals his entire invading army, a mix of Chitauri, Leviathians, Outriders, and the Black Order. This was Tony's vision of the Endgame. Cap's shield was broken, Black Widow was dead, an alien army was ready to invade Earth, and nobody was left to stop them. That is exactly what Tony saw in Age of Ultron in his vision. Even though it was a hopeless match, Captain America would never give up. This is another moment that truly shows us that no matter what happens, Captain America will always stand back up to fight until he is literally destroyed and 100% dead. Single-handedly marching towards Thanos and his entire army to stand up to them is saying: "I can do this all day," without actually saying it. Steve is still that kid from Brooklyn who stood up to the bully in that alley, and this time, the bully is Thanos and his army. The visual shots of Captain America summoning Thor's hammer and of him walking with a broken shield straight into Thanos's army, ready to fight them all are some of the best visual effects ever. And now, we get to the most epic, most iconic, the GOAT of all epic scenes. Right when Steve thinks its all over, he suddenly hears a voice. The words sound somewhat familiar. He's heard them before, about 9 years ago: "On your left." It was Sam. Right on his left, a portal opens, and out of it comes ... Black Panther, followed by Okoye and Shuri. T'Challa nods at Steve, ready to fight. Suddenly the soundtrack kicks in as Falcon flies in overhead. Then, on another side opens another portal, this one from Titan and we see Dr. Strange, the Master of the Mystic Arts himself, who planned this all. Along with him are Star-Lord, Drax, Mantis, and finally Spider-Man. Cap smiles and sighs, rejoicing. Portals open everywhere and everyone comes through. The New Asgardians from New Asgard, the Ravagers from their various planets, and Wong and all the Sorcerers from around the world. M'Baku and the entire Wakandan army follow out along with Bucky and Groot. Wasp flies in as well, and Scarlet Witch drops in from above. Nebula, Hawkeye, and Gamora re-enter the battle as well. Just when we think they're all here, Ant-Man grows to 100 feet tall and drops of Professor Hulk, War Machine, and Rocket. Shocked and stunned, Thor and Iron Man get back up as well. Then the music switches back to the classic Avengers theme, but so much more epic this time. From six heroes circling up to defend the city, it had now become a whole army of heroes defending the Universe. Cap sees what's happened and now has a determined look on his face ready to lead everyone into battle. As the music continues, The Avengers all get ready to fight. Summoning the hammer again, Cap says the iconic line in the most epic and satisfying way possible. "Avengers ... Assemble." It all goes crazy from there. The main Avengers theme starts as all the heroes charge into battle. I have never seen anything like this in any movie to this scale. I will always remember seeing Endgame in the theater for the first time. It's an experience I wish I could relive. Avengers: Endgame was the best and most memorable time I've ever had in any theater and I don't know if any film will ever top this experience, and this scene is probably a main reason why. I've grown up watching these characters and finally seeing them all throw down like this was just insane. The ending of Avengers: Endgame is near perfect. The funeral for Tony Stark was the best possible tribute to him and Tony's self-made eulogy is heartbreaking and loving at the same time. And of course, we will never forget, "I love you 3000." All the original Avengers have reached their conclusion and their story is at its close. Avengers: Endgame was the end of an era, and it sure ended it in style. And of course, the final closing for the original 6 Avengers was the credits scene. My God, I have never seen the Credits leave so much impact. but they do in Endgame, not just because its the last one, but the way they are structured makes us feel like we're at the end. We slowly see all the heroes and their actors one by one, and when we finally get to the original 6, the music changes. We see the characters and their scenes in the background one by one, and with their name, comes their signature. Jeremy Renner, Scarlet Johannson, Mark Ruffalo, Chris Hemsworth, Chris Evans, and finally Robert Downey Jr.
I simply love it 3000
Inconsistent tone, out of character moments, poor pacing, forced callbacks to past events and pop culture references, and so many plot holes. This movie is mediocre at best.

EDIT** After rewatching 2 years later, I think Endgame has aged well and I added a half star to make it 4.5/5. Now that I already know the story choices they make (even if I don't love them all), the quality of this movie stands out more to me. The human drama is at the best it has ever been in the MCU- and particularly the first half takes time to slow things down with tons of character moments that feel very earned. The actors all give their best performances, and I found myself enjoying the small scenes of emotional dialogue perhaps even more than the big action moments (although those are blast too). 

Endgame is an extremely well made film, but for me it falls short of being a perfect conclusion and follow-up to the highs reached by Infinity War. Endgame ends up being an emotional, slow-burn the majority of the story, leaving most of the spectacle for the final act. My main problems with Endgame come down to the story. **SPOILERS** A couple issues I had include: 
1. Hulk becomes Professor Hulk offscreen, probably the biggest development his character has had in the entire course of the MCU happens in a throwaway line of dialogue played for comedic effect. Then he is sidelined the rest of the movie and is virtually absent in the final battle despite being a flagship marvel character. Most disappointing was Hulk not getting the rematch with Thanos he seemed obviously set up for in Infinity War. 
2. Iron Man once again dominates the storyline, being the one who both solves time travel (conveniently and after almost no effort) and ultimately snaps Thanos and company out of existence. It's not that I don't like his character, it's just that I want to feel like the MCU is bigger than this one character, he takes the spotlight in all 4 Avenger movies, his own trilogy, and plays a major role in Civil War, Homecoming, and Far from Home. Everything has to revolve around Tony while other interesting and more powerful characters get sidelined. 
3. Time travel seemed like a convenient cop out for the writers to solve the story. Something unbelievably terrible happens so our heroes solve it with time travel. Terminator, X-men Days of Future Past, Looper, Deadpool 2- we've seen it so many times. After Infinity War's dramatic ending I guess I was hoping for something a bit more original and creative to fix the snap. 
4. The final battle doesn't carry the same weight and intensity of the Wakanda charge. Part of this is the fully CGI setting and part is that by the time all heroes show up we know victory is inevitable. Even though we know they will win, it would carry more weight if they left some uncertainty/suspense all the way through the battle's end (think of the intensity of the final moments at the Black Gate battle at ROTK). It really comes down to Tony, Thor, and Captain fighting Thanos, and everything else just feels like a nice background rather than a true fight to the death between two armies. 
5. Fat Thor was funny at first, but it overstayed its welcome. Infinity War perfected his character, balancing Thor's comedic side with the fact that he is still a formidable warrior on a quest for vengeance. Instead Thor remains a punchline throughout the Endgame, which was really a letdown considering how badass he was in IW. IW starts with Thor getting his ass kicked by Thanos, and ends with him redeeming himself by coming back more powerful than ever to bury his axe in Thanos' chest. Now we have him reverting back to becoming an overweight loser getting his ass kicked by Thanos, which makes his overall arc less satisfying. 

All that being said this is still a very good movie. The visuals, directing, acting, cinematography, and soundtrack are all fantastic. It wraps up many loose ends of the MCU while still leaving many other stories to be told, I just was left slightly disappointed by several story elements.

There can be only so many of those franchise spanning sprawling epic kind of films.

Not that the Russo brothers don't know how to pull it off; the directing team have already proven their astounding capacity to handle a veritable menagerie of super-beings thrown in into a tapestry of increasingly complex plot-lines since they directed CAPTAIN AMERICA: THE WINTER SOLDIER back in 2014. While this film presented a fascinating spy drama plot delving into a vast conspiracy shaking the foundations of S.H.I.E.L.D. all the while exploring Captain America's survivor's guilt, the following 2 films, 2016's CAPTAIN AMERICA: CIVIL WAR, and last year's AVENGERS: INFINITY WAR, steered clear of character developments to focus on bringing bigger and bigger spectacles putting a growing number of heroes in jeopardy.

With CIVIL WAR, INFINITY WAR and now AVENGERS ENDGAME, Anthony and Joe Russo have successfully upped the ante and they have, beyond all expectations, managed to win with flying colors.

The film has its limited appeal (although the MCU series' amazing profitability seems to warrant such a gamble) ;  it will make most sense to the fans who have seen most of the previous films in the series, very much like it was the case with INFINITY WAR, but even more so, as the plot requires to have a good knowledge of the previous films, not only to fully appreciate the references, but to fully care for characters that shows up onscreen for often less than a minute. Granted, some appearances, albeit short, can pack quite a wallop, and the script by MCU veterans Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely manages to adroitly unravel so much drama, humor and action in the epic 3 hour long duration of the movie that you sometimes are left with no time to ponder on the brevity of some sub-plots.

There is a multitude of such fascinating turns in the story that would deserve their own movie by themselves, and that may indeed feed the plots for upcoming installments of some of the solo stories to come, but are left as mere teases, just enough to provide information, but not quite enough for the emotion to fully hits. One such example is Scott Lang (Ant-Man, played with effortless charm by Paul Rudd) returning home after vanishing for 5 years in the Quantum Realm. Discovering a land wounded by Thanos' (a superb Josh Brolin) world-shattering snap, where half of the world's population was turned to dust, leaving the survivors battered and weary, still reeling under the shock of the loss of their loved ones. When Lang comes home, he is met with the results of his long absence, which in itself might have deserved more screen time. But then again, as stated, the film is already clocking at 3 hours, and there is barely anything that should be cut in the first place.

This is not to say that the film is all sound and fury with nary an emotion to be felt. In fact the beginning of the film has a poignant melancholy to it, where the surviving heroes from ''the snap'' are still reeling from the ultimate defeat from the last film. And there is still plenty of humor to be found, including Chris Hemsworth's increasingly comedic interpretation of Thor, which was the highlight of THOR: RAGNAROK by Taika Waititi 2 years ago. I'm not certain his deconstruction of the God of Thunder will please longtime fans, but he, alongside Mark Ruffalo's Hulk, provides most of the laughs in the film.

But as was the case in the previous films by the Russo Brothers, the emotional center of the film is definitely Captain America and Iron Man, who benefits from the deepest characterization and some of the best scenes from the film. Robert Downey's Tony Stark has been the linchpin of the MCU ever since Jon Favreau's IRON MAN in 2008, and his character stands in the film as the one with the most to lose if he returns to the fray in a desperate attempt to save the World once again from the threat of Thanos. And Steve Rogers, beautifully portrayed by an earnest Chris Evans, will have the crowd cheering in one of the most fan-pleasing scene I've seen in years, which had me yell ''Oh yeah!'' in the theater.

The film is not perfect, of course. No film really is. The pacing can be all over the place, and it can leave a lot of questions unanswered. But it never leaves you much time to ponder. Some moments can be predictable, but some moments can be completely, utterly shocking. But it is a perfect wrap-up of this first 11 years of Marvel movies, bringing fun, thrills, and a fair amount of tears in its wake.

 But after all the insane magnitude of these crossover story-lines, I am hoping for a bit of a break. Don't get me wrong; I am glad to see the saga of the Infinity Stones draw to a close and have enjoyed the ride. But I hope it takes a few films before we are taken on another one of those franchise-spanning saga. Like a roller coaster ride, it can be tremendously exciting  yet exhausting.

Avengers: Endgame, directed once again by the Russo Brothers, was one of the most memorable films I've ever seen, being the best movie theater experience I've ever had! The Russo Brothers gathered everyone together, one last time, to go out with an absolute bang, but it didn't come without a few flaws. The premise of the film had it's tropes, but due to the great amount of heart, powerful themes, emotion and tention, it kept things moving forward, with great energy! Although there are so many memorable scenes, all of the content they tried to squeeze in, set up for a lot of plot gaps, conveniences, and nitpicks, but nothing completely threw me out of the film. Similar to Infinity War, the way the Russo Brothers structured the scenes, didn't make for the best flowing narrative, creating too much filler, in order to hit that three hour mark. They tried to incorporate almost everything that we've learned in the past, creating a lot of fan service moments, throwing the pace and focus of the film off. The Russo Brothers seemed to have had a tough time trying to balance all of the tones, where at some moments, they play off eachother nicely, and some other times, it can almost take you out of the film.

It's crazy that, after twenty-two films, the creative team is still finding ways to flesh out, and develop our characters! Even though there are a few questionable character archs given to some of our heroes, you still have to give credit to the creative team, for doing something new, while still keeping the comics relevant. There are so many great character moments in this film, and I'd honestly go as far as saying that, it had just as many, if not, a few more moments than Infinity War. Markus and McFeely did a great job grounding everyone's character, giving everyone a well understood motive, that the audience can create an emotional bond with. This was by far the most emotional film of the Infinity Saga, but, by every character bringing their A-game to the set, it brings the emotions up to an eleven. One of the main issues I had with the characters, on the side of some of the archs, is the balancing. As said before, it's going to be tough to balance all of this talent on screen at once, but they created a better situation for themselves, and didn't quite capitalize on it.

Given for the amount of content they had to put into form, the screenplay by Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely, was pretty good. They created a lot of memorable pieces of dialogue, while balancing the comedy better this time around. The only issues I had with the script, was some ideas and characters went a little underdeveloped; other than that, this was a pretty well written script.

The action of this film was off the walls! Though it can get a little sloppy, and convenient at times, they still managed to craft these amazing, high octane action sequences, including the most memorable and known sequence of all superhero films!

Overall, there are more than a few notable issues with this film, but I just really enjoy Avengers: Endgame! I wouldn't go as far as saying that it belongs at the top of your list, but it definitely belongs around the top ten!

The characters have depth that you can feel, the emotions are more real and more palpable, the jokes are truly and genuinely funny (not corny, actually funny), and the deaths are just plain gut wrenching. Oh and the action is absolutely spectacular. By the time the final battle took place I was so invested in the story and the characters that every twist and turn of it had me on the edge of my seat. I literally got chills when Captain America called out “Avengers... assemble!” Hats off to the Russo brothers, they ended the series in perfectly epic fashion.

The Avengers: Endgame is an action film by directors Anthony and Joe Russo. It brings together almost all Marvels' superheroes, played by some popular actors. For instance Robert Downey Jr. as Iron Man, Chris Hemsworth as Thor , Benedict Cumberbatch as Doctor Strange or my favorite actor Chris Evans as Captain America and many others well-known actors.
The plot of the film is quite predictable. The main villain is, of course, Thanos, like in the previous part. He was killed by Thor, but returned to finish his idea of killing half of the galaxy with the help of six infinity stones. Therefore only Avengers can stop him, but there are only half of them. Why? You should probably know from the previous part.
This part of Avengers is not so funny. It was more about relationships and understanding problems between Avengers, for example when Robert Downey Jr. as Tony Stark invents a time machine and helps half of Avengers return to the past and find the infinity stones. But the script and plot are still not boring and there are a lot of impressive moments and spectacular scenes, like the final battle scene. This scene is the best one which I have ever seen. But for me the most memorable scene was when Iron Man takes infinity stones from Thanos, uses it and says "And I… am…. IRON MAN" and snaps his fingers…
To sum up, Brothers Russo have created one of the best action and grossing film ever. I think that this film has something for everyone. So don't miss it!

Okay enough wrap-up to the Avengers storyline, but it takes three hours to do it! Two key characters don't make it to the final credits. And, time travel is used to solve the problem of restoring things to their proper order. Now, time travel is absolutely my biggest pet peeve in science fiction, because it is usually just a lazy way of fixing things when you run out of ideas, like the screenwriters do here. And, Thanos is just a boring villain. He is evil for the sake of being evil, and is purely one dimensional. Plus, the CGI for his character just isn't there yet, so you are already not buying him as a character. Rudimentary cinematography and film score don't help things too much.

This film will be around forever like Star Wars.

This film both exceeded my expectations and unfortunately left me with a mixed bag to pick at. I'm first going to delve deep into the positives of this film, because boy are there a bunch to pick from. First off, the cast in this film are absolutely incredible, Robert Downey Jr., Chris Evans, Paul Rudd, Mark Ruffalo, Scarlett Johansson etc. everyone was great. It was so breathtaking to see all of my favourite heroes finally coming together to battle one last time, for now anyway. The score was perfectly composed by the great Alan Silvestri as it holds one of the most memorable MCU score tracks to date, 'Portals'. The CGI Team did an amazing job because this film looks visually stunning. The fight scenes are amazingly choreographed so hats off to the choreography team for doing such a great job. 

Now like all films, they have their flaws, and this film definitely has its fair share of them. First off, this film was all about undoing the events that occurred in Infinity War, so that already makes you guess at what is to be expected. Because at the end of Infinity War, our Heroes lost together for the very first time, they failed. Endgame was pretty much a way of telling people "Oh hey its okay the remaining Avengers will figure out a way to fix this and everyone will live happily ever after" making Infinity War's ending less impactful, for me anyway. But, with fixing the damage, comes big consequences for our Heroes, and there are definitely a lot of consequences for them in Endgame, which makes the film more or less worthwhile in the end. 

So all in all, this film packs in pretty much everything you would expect in a grand finale of a universe, 11 years in the making. So I highly recommend this film as it is a really fun and entertaining film to watch with some very awesome and memorable moments you will have stuck in your head for a long time. 

Enjoy!

Over the last 11 years, Marvel Studios has built a franchise unlike anything the movie world has ever seen before. More than just launching an incredible run of multiple series that each center on unique characters and establish their own specific aesthetics, they've also maintained an immensely complex continuity that expands with each new story. Every filmmaker who contributes to the universe adds a new piece to the puzzle, carving out something different and diverse that is also crafted to add to the bigger picture.

Within this approach there are gradients, and it results in two basic kinds of Marvel Studios films. On one side you have titles like Captain America: The Winter Soldier and Guardians Of The Galaxy, which find their own corner of the expansive world and use that specific real estate for relatively contained storytelling. On the other side there are titles like The Avengers and Captain America: Civil War, which are designed with the entire scope of the franchise in mind, and utilize specific details and elements of the larger continuity to create something both reflective and new.

As tremendous and exceptional as the movies in the former category can be (and that's pretty extreme), it's those in the latter that make the Marvel Cinematic Universe truly special. Simply making a cogent and entertaining blockbuster is a ridiculous challenge all by itself, so you'd think that simultaneously incorporating the massive details of multiple other massive films would be practically impossible. And yet, the studio has been successful time and time again.

This brings us to Joe and Anthony Russo's Avengers: Endgame – a film that has been specifically described over the last four-and-a-half years as the movie that would be the ultimate capstone for the franchise, and exist as the story to which all of the previous 21 chapters have been leading. Obviously that's an incredible amount of hype, and the end result is that it's now considered one of the most anticipated releases in history… but what's even more utterly spectacular is the fact that every ounce of that hype is totally justified.

Simply put, Avengers: Endgame is one of the most ambitious, entertaining, emotional, and stunning blockbusters we've ever seen, and the best film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe canon thus far.

Certain aspects and new directions they took with characters could be seen as to risky and not how we would expect them to act, and certain things aren't always the same as we remember them. However the time travel in this movie brings us nostalgia to past movies and reminds of what we went through to get here. Finally the ending brought back all the characters we know and love to take down the villain they have been hyping up for years to be the avengers final showdown. The sacrifices the characters are willing to make in this movie and the stakes feel very refreshing for a genre where we always expect the good guys to win and no one gets hurt permanently. Great enjoyable movie that was a huge payoff for marvel fans and despite several risky moves, this will go down as one of the most memorable movies of all time.

A atmosfera é de luto. Se no filme anterior, o protagonista era o Thanos, aqui o foco é completamente direcionado a equipe, que precisa lidar com seu fracasso e seguir em frente. Mas como?! Após perceber que não havia mais volta, anos se passam, a vida seguiu, novos vínculos são criados, e agora de novo há o que se perder. Então, quando surge uma nova solução, arriscar valeria a pena?

EndGame tem uma peculiaridade. Ele tenta agradar a todos e consegue isso de forma surpreendente. Temos Fan Services que funcionam muito bem, batalhas épicas e homenagens a toda a historia da fase no cinema. Temos diversas cenas de puro dialogo, o que nos aproxima muito dos personagens. As atuações estão muito boas - você sente que a maioria dos atores se encontraram ali. A OST é de arrepiar e a fotografia estonteante. 

De longe, esse é o filme mais emocionante da saga. Com tantos diálogos, emoções, medo, sacrifícios e surpresas, é normal se encontrar chorando numa cena ou outra. Inclusive, o final belíssimo é um presente não só para o Steve Rogers como para os amantes do amor. 

Avengers: Endgame tem uma conclusão histórica, com um dos planos mais ambiciosos já feitos. Toda homenagem feita a sua trajetória, aos personagens e aos fans é emocionante, e não importa quantas vezes o veja, tu vai se emocionar!

Endgame has its flaws, very obvious ones but the highs of this movie outweigh the negatives by far; this is a perfect ending to the 22 film story of the MCU. Robert Downey Jr and Chris Evans give their best performances, the visuals are incredible, the stakes are real, the suspense is there, the first hour does a perfect job of showing us the effects of the snap, Alan Silvestri's score is probably the best of the MCU, the second hour is filled with well-deserved fan service and great character moments and the third hour has easily the best momnets of the MCU and is the perfect finale. Some may argue it's just a fan service movie but that's what it's meant to be and it earned it. It's meant to be a reward for those who've been fans of the MCU and I'm so happy with what we got. Take notes X-Men, this is how you end a franchise.

A wrap of many key threads from over twenty movies, every character gets a moment and the MCU's big two, Cap and Stark, get to complete their arcs in satisfying ways. It cannot be understated what an achievement this is. It applies a lot of easter eggs and fan service as it looks over the history of the franchise and it has earned this indulgence. Yet it does also suffer slighty from Return of the King syndrome; it sends so much time ticking off the list of things to cover it sometimes feels like the heart of the story gets lost. The plot mechanics to get us there don't make that much sense, and it feels less tight than previous Avengers films, but in a way as the writers throw everything at the wall to see what sticks, this represents the heroes' desperate race for survival as they do the same. Ultimately, it comes down to this universe's mantra; when you are having fun along the way does it matter?

Endgame is the culmination of the Infinity Saga's 10 year run of MCU films. It's a massive film, filled with amazing visual effects, tons of fan service, great action sequences, and a terrific sendoff for a beloved character. 'I am Iron Man' will forever be immortalized as the most badass superhero moment in the entire MCU, bar none. Once again, the Russo brothers did a fantastic job balancing tone throughout the film. Despite the gloom that completely enveloped the first 30 minutes or so of the film, they managed to add in a few lighthearted moments that set the stage for future tonal shifts in the film. I felt the humor was welcomed and, at times, downright hilarious. Steve Rogers v. Steve Rogers is a moment most soon won't forget. And that is most definitely America's ass (trademark). However, though the fan service was excellent, it severely detracts from the re-watch potential of the film. I was surprised, elated, and emotionally fulfilled from my first watch-through and the countless fan service moments will never have that same impact upon re-watching the movie (which is why I will likely never watch it again). The emotional moments were fully earned and I cried in the theater (it was the cheeseburger line), something that rarely happens to me. After 10 years of watching these characters grow and interact with one another, I felt that the arcs for Tony and Steve were perfect in every which way. Also, I'm proud to say that I predicted the final shots of the film between Peggy and Steve and I still get chills thinking about it. The Russo brothers created the perfect culminating film for the MCU but unfortunately, the over-abundance of fan-service makes this an impossible film to enjoy more than once and for me, detracts from the overall score. Nevertheless, this is still a great MCU film and the Russos have more than earned their rest.

You’ll love this movie 3,000. An emotional and satisfying conclusion to the Infinity Saga. Very good screenplay, score, and visual effects. The performances of Robert Downey Jr, Chris Evans, Chris Hemsworth, Scarlett Johansson, Jeremy Renner, Paul Rudd, Karen Gillan, and Don Cheadle were exceptional. The motion capture performances of Mark Ruffalo and Josh Brolin were also exceptional as was the voice performance of Bradley Cooper. Credit the directors Joe and Anthony Russo and Kevin Feige and the entire team at Marvel Studios for orchestrating this film and making it come to life. The biggest movie you’ll ever see and many characters arcs are wrapped up in the film. Credit to Marvel Studios for creating something that will probably never be replicated again in film industry.

A fantastic conclusion to ten years of these unique act-packed films. The Russo brothers once again bring an epic showdown with our favorite heroes. The movie isn't necessarily a cult classic what with it breaking box office records and what not, but wrapping up ten years of relatable, colorful, and well-directed action films is certainly something to go for. It's hard telling exactly what will happen next when it comes to the future success of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, but it's likely not going to top the current momentum for a while, if ever. Overall, the film has a fairly complex yet understandable storyline and is pretty unpredictable at times. It should remain quite a classic to MCU fans like myself and not just Marvel fans in general (i.e. comic books, Stan Lee, etc.).

It had good graphics, and there were a few parts that were really good. Natasha's sacrifice being one of them. But there were soooo many things wrong with the conclusion to a decades worth of movies. The girl power moment was not empowering, it felt forced. Steve's ending was a complete setback to his character development. Gay Joe Russo??? Really??? I'm supposed to be impressed that they included a gay character for 30 seconds and it was Joe Russo? Yeah, not impressed. Bucky getting an itsy bitsy amount of screentime. Antman was funny, as always. Tony's death was touching, even though he's my least favorite character for a lot of reasons. Overall, would I watch this again? My answer is a definitive no. There were more things wrong with this movie than there were right. I'm pretending the last ten minutes didn't happen. That Captain America didn't turn into a selfish jerk and go back to the past, forcing Peggy to choose him. He still could have retired without resorting to running away. The best thing to come out of this movie is the Falcon and Winter Soldier television show. Will never see anything by the Russo brothers again because of how bad they screwed up so many characters.

The epic conclusion to the Infinity Saga, Avengers: Endgame provides a satisfying ending that exceeds ever fanboy's wildest expectations.

[⭐️99%]

Avengers: Endgame (2019) absolutely smashes the landing and delivers one of the most satisfying experiences in cinema history. The super hero genre has never been taken too seriously in terms of ‘quality cinema' however amongst others, this entry proves that they are more than action flicks. For a casual viewer or a die hard Marvel fan, there is enjoyment for all. Not only does Avengers: Endgame (2019) pay off years of fan service which had been carefully crafted throughout the MCU's existence, but it does it in a way which felt both natural and proper.

In the many MCU movies up to this point, none had a longer duration than Avengers: Endgame (2019), but you only really feel that long runtime once the film is completed and you have time to reflect on the events you witnessed. Every character gets their moment, whether they are for the main characters like Steve Rogers and Tony Stark, or smaller ones like Nebula and Clint Barton.

Avengers: Endgame (2019) is the perfect Marvel movie, beside the handling of Thor which may annoy some, however there is no doubt that this film deserves the stature of praise it has received. Delivering a roller coaster of emotions, from comedic laughs, rolling tears, to gasps of shock and screams of happiness, this film has it all.
Avenger's Endgame ties the threads of the MCU in a compelling manor, with the added bonus of endearing characters, great visuals, and the same pounding score as always.

I think that avengers endgame is one of the most awesome movies that was released this century and I recommend for everyone to watch it i want to say that i didn't cry that much when another movie ended before.
Fantastic ending to the Infinity Saga.

I would be lying to you if I said I didn't love this movie. I did, every single minute of it. Endgame is the perfect culmination of the pop culture phenomenon known as the MCU. The acting is terrific, the special effects are mind boggling, and the emotion conveyed through a comic book story is unreal. Who would have thought we would get a movie like Endgame and have it be great. The only reason it's not a five is because of the pacing. I could not have been happier walking out of the theater.

You simply can't introduce time travel in the Final Episode. You can't undo all the deaths as if they were nothing; I did read a book about the history of Marvel comics where Stan Lee wanted to sell the illusion of change and while this is exactly that. I'm allowed to jot like the core idea of what Stan Lee wanted from Marvel. I side more with Jack Kirby on wanting my movies with real irreversible changes.

In some interview they tried to explain away the plotholes with the infamous phrase: "A wizard did it" from the Xhena parody Q&A from the Simpsons Tree House of Horror's Halloween episode.

When it comes to Marvel crossover conclusions involving time travel; X-men Days of Future Past (specially the eXtentded Rogue Cut) is better than this. Also the Back to the Future this movie jokes about and tries to homage; is a thousand years better than this, Avengers Endgame is the Jaws XXII that Back to the Future II joked would happen in the future.

Marvel has not only jumped the Shark; it has jumped the Fonzy as shown by the prequel Captain Marvel showing a fight on space above Fonzy merchandise. I don't understand why people aren't angry. But as someone who likes grounded movies i didn't liked this.

The way time travel is done; it tries to survive on nostalgia rather than earning a good story. I didn't liked most of the uneven MCU prequels; so this feels unearned. 

Also the Hawkeye kids would of had been better orphan, than raised by a Punisher turned vengeful bloody cold killer Hawkeye father. The film sacrificed; and that's the thing, characters never face consequences. We never see what they learned, they just win because they had time-travel but they never overcome their personal flaws on the way the adult-kids from IT do (without overcoming any specific flaws; all characters are interchangeable and that makes the movie worse).

The worse example of characters not learning anything is Captain America, even if one simpatizes with him missing his girl that got away. Creating an alternative timeline to be with her is creepy and unethical; specially because she had already aged and died of natural causes; after having a life of her own. Is wrong, also I mean they altered some timelines which is wrong. Normal time travel mechanics would had been better. I don't know it feels like they won by cheating, because they won without personal growing up and maturing if feels unearned and hollow (Star Wars III: Revenge of the Sith failure in comparison to the victory in VI: Return of the Jedi a great example of overcoming flaws and winning, even if JJ Abrams is such a bad writet that IX:Rise of Skywalker has the characters winning by doing the exact same things deemed as failures in the previous movies).

2019 was a year of lackluster endings; part of the problem of reviving characters is that the "death" always feels fake. 

The positive thing I can say is the acting is good, the MCU VFX designs have always been to cartoonish for my taste; even if the effects are good. I would say too much CGI. The worst part is that the generic debris was so generic that action was hard to follow; hard to know where anyone was standing and thus what was happening.

I feel that the criticized Godzilla King of the Monster handled the envioremental storyline, which I feel should had been the core of this movie; so much better. The population measure control there is Godzilla and the deaths are permanent; accepted and the villian wins because the enviorement is shown less contaminated where Godzilla attacked. Godzilla justified the villian attack by saying human overpopulation causes contamination; whereas Thanos motivations get lost due to this Sequel forgetting them completely and turning him into a generic villian.

The best movie in the MCU. It took all the build up from the last 11 years of the MCU and delivered one of the most epic, emotional and crowd-pleasing movies that Marvel has made. No characters feel underutilised, the time-heist is entertaining and has tons of MCU callbacks and Professor Hulk is a great change up for the character. The final battle is one of my favourite scenes in any movie as it takes all the characters we know and love (including Howard the Duck!) into one epic finale against one of the most iconic movie villains ever. Fat Thor is frustrating and Thanos does become very underdeveloped compared to Infinity War, but neither of these complaints really bother me that much. Endgame is incredible!

I guess this is what they call a monumental cinematic experience. I'm not a big Marvel fan and certainly wasn't an Avengers fan, but this two-part conclusion to The Infinity Saga is as good as movies get. Not forgetting I'm usually quite critical of blockbusters.

Having lost someone close to me with the simultaneous mixture of long and drawn out and extremely quickly as certain diseases will do; I found Avengers Endgame difficult to watch but only because it was beautiful and painful.
There are two ways to enjoy this movie, one as a fun time heist, throwback, exciting blockbuster with some snappy oneliners and a healthy dose of gloss, the closure of some main character arcs and some significant resolution (although also with a heady dose of sequel potential of course.). 

The other way to view this movie is a movie in touch with the heart of grief and loss, and also just losing. It's deeply sad throughout and people try to put a brave face on as you do, but grief is no slouch and it clearly takes constant work for them all just to buck up and rally around another one of sad-faced Captain America's many speeches. 
It all culminates in the death of Iron Man and the eventual death of Captain America and both men get what they want. Lives without all this pain; The burden of responsibility and honour. When Stark dies it's quick but it feels earned, and when Potts leans in to him and allows him to go, he doesn't register anything on his face because he's dying. But you hope he registers it somewhere before he does. 
I'd need to see it again to appreciate the nuances and the Easter eggs but I was profoundly moved by watching these people (characters) we know well by now, in the kinds of pain we will all go through. And strangely it overtook my experience of the movie but not in a bad way. 

So I gave it 5 stars. When I wash it clean from my mind and watch it again. I'll be able to assess its many levels, achievements and flaws. But as a film about loss. It's superbly layered and surprisingly effective and therefore I say it's pretty much succeeded on a human level. For something with a massive green dude in spectacles and fat Thor in it, that's saying something.

While some call this a masterpiece and others think it's only decent and saved by the finale, I am in between these two groups. While I was entertained by many scenes before the final act like those with time travel, I do feel that there are some major flaws. Some flaws are the slow pacing in the beginning, the lack of character development for the heroes and Thanos, the unfortunate focus on the bland Nebula, and the last 15 minutes after the final battle that really drag. I feel that 2/3 of this movie is Marvel at its finest while the rest is mediocre. I don't hate anything about this film which is why it warrants a 9 out o 10, but the flaws keep it from being Marvel's best work.

What this movie pulled off was absolutely stunning. The last time so many characters were pulled off well was in Avengers: Infinity War. The third act was absolutely brilliant and was arguably the best hyped action scene of the decade, if not of all time. The consequences of the snap are laid clear, half the universe truly is gone. They even do a great job of showing how the survivors have changed over the last five years. The first hour of the movie has extremely slow pacing and isn't something worth rewatching. The second act is also fairly slow, but starts getting a good amount of progress. I can't stress enough how epic the third act was, it brings you on an emotional roller coaster that will make you view everything else as inferior once you finish it. Its low points were still high and its high points were the highest you can get. 9/10, with what they were given, this is probably the best the Russo brothers could've ever done with this. They never cease to surprise me with some of the greatest movies I'll see all year.
It delivers in its climax, but it bored me in the other 2 hours and I still don't like the characters. 41/100
Melhor filme do ano!

Entertaining and at times majestic, though I was almost never surprised. We've been made to be invested in these characters by years of compelling storylines, and it is a unique art form to bring so many great personalities together into a single epic film. Still there are moments that just feel wrong (fat drunk Thor) or aggressively attempting social messaging (the "women" somehow all coming together on the battlefield), and it's enough of that sort of thing that after the first viewing, it feels obnoxious.

If you love the Avengers world and characters I'm sure you'll enjoy this. However, for me it was pretty dull for the most part. 3 hrs for no good reason as the first half is just them moping about with little action. What they did to the Hulk and Thor characters was ridiculous. It's not a spoiler to say there's a half decent battle in there, although it looks like a video game. I liked the Avengers films but that's enough of it now. I'm still happy to see more from Spiderman, Guardians of The Galaxy and Black Panther but kinda bored with the rest of them. This is an ok film to pass the time but it's no great loss if you never get round to it.

Once more in to the breach. This was a fitting finale and an earnest attempt at a love letter to the fans. However, not all the choices sit flawlessly or well with me personally. Good ending that should have been better.
Not as good as Infinity War but an epic epilogue to an amazing saga.

All I am going to say is that Avengers Endgame lives up to the previous 22 films, along with delivering fresh new aspects, along with fan-favorite moments which will greatly satisfy the comic book audience.
I don't think this movie could have been anymore perfect. It is an amazing end to a long and fantastic journey. I'm so glad to be alive to witness the epicness of this movie.

As the culmination of the MCU - this film has a lot of pay off for Marvel fans. There's so many cool geeky fan moments (especially the last 30 minutes). The film has a monumental task of trying to bring closure to so many characters and succeeds for the most part. I feel the time travel premise a little bit lazy which introduces multiple plot holes - but the geek inside me didn't care as I was captivated by what was on screen. Overall I think Infinity War is the better film, but this is a satisfying conclusion to this section of the MCU.

While to truly appreciate it you have to have followed the entire MCU, I think that even if you have not followed the MCU you would enjoy.

With its amazing action scenes, great writing, great directing, solid plot, compelling characters, character development, character growth and mature themes such as depression, grief, acceptance and family/relationships. Even if you are not a fan of the MCU it's a film worth watching but truly rewarding if you have followed the MCU.

Overall it's a great conclusion and a great send off to the infinity saga.

This movie honestly is one of the most beautiful movies of all time. Everything about it is great this movie pulled something no other could have, it concluded the Infinity Saga. The characters were amazing as always, the story although pretty messy was amazing and for a movie that is 3 hours you would expect to be boring but it isn't I really can't describe this movie with words. The music, the ending, the character's arcs, the action scenes, the dialogue were from another world and I never cried or got invested in a movie so much like in this one

I'm somewhat biased as I grew up reading Marvel comics but for me Endgame – the culmination of the 21 Marvel films before it – is a sublime movie experience. It deals with it's subject matter with a great affection and has the perfect amount of sentimentality, comedy, action and exposition to make it's run time of 3 hours not seem long enough. The story arc of it's protagonists such as Captain America and Iron Man from their first solo films to Endgame is a work of ingenious planning and ultimately fulfilling. It's a bit embarrassing but this is only film to ever make me shout out with joy during a cinematic experience. To quote the great Stan Lee "Excelsior" – but I don't see how any superhero film can hope to reach greater heights than this.

Endgame is definitely a worthy ending for the Avengers. With grand CGI and a story even better than Infinity War, the movie truly is a spectacle, and there's not one boring moment in its quite long 3 hour runtime. The finale, my favorite scene in the movie, is a fitting tribute to RDJ, too. As a longtime fan of Marvel, I can say that Endgame is frankly the best movie in all of the MCU.

I really enjoyed this movie, but there were just a few things that ticked me off. First off is Thanos. Thanos was probably the most fleshed-out character we have ever seen in an MCU film, he has a reason for wiping out half of the universe. But in this, he is a ruthless cold-blooded killer, who decides to instead murder everything. He went from wanting to save our future, to wanting to destroy it. My second problem is how easily Tony Stark discovers how time travel works. It is a complete Ex Machina. But nevertheless, I enjoyed this movie. I might watch it again in the future, but it's not the type of movie I am dying to see again.

Endgame by far was one of the largest, most anticipated endings to an equally impressive cliffhanger presented by Avengers: Infinity War. The movie, directed by acclaimed producers Anthony and Joe Russo, was the peak of the series of the Avengers. The movie presents an amazing sequence of battle scenes created by top-notch CGI and VFX artists. Not only that, but the storyline not only presented in the movie but the entire series of the film, is if not exceptional, then out of this world, literally, with a star trek like fantasy of spaceships zooming all over the galaxy to the the present and sci-fi future like technology of Ironman. The movie, played by beloved actors such as Tom Holland and Robert Downey Jr., brought even more applaud to the much-loved ending sequence to the final film of the popular and well-constructed series of movies. That, by far, makes Endgame one of the best movies ever created.

As a conclusion to over a decades worth of storytelling, it's got a lot to live up to, and it's about as good as you could really hope for it to be.  Overall, I really do like Infinity War better.  At the end of the day, Infinity War was just a wildly new experience, it was such a gamechanger and crowd-pleaser.  Not only that, Infinity War I think had a better final battle.  This final battle, while boasting the biggest ensemble of Marvel heroes we've ever seen on screen, is weirdly dark and muddied in CGI scenery compared to the battle at Wakanda from Infinity War.  Also I hate Professor Hulk, he's just not that fun.  Okay so those are my criticisms, what did I like about the movie?  I guess everything else?  The time travel plot let's us revisit and honor some old moments in Marvel with a new lens in sort of a Back to the Future Part 2 way that's a lot of fun, and it brings back some characters I didn't think we'd ever see again.  The movie has a big emotional core, and a climactic end that is godamn powerful.  This movie juggles a lot.  Seriously this is like watching someone juggle 10 flaming chainsaws, it's a godamn miracle it works at all.  That it works this well is even more of a miracle.  It's an imperfect movie, but perfectly satisfying conclusion to this arc of the Marvel saga.
