Seeing this opening weekend was perhaps the best cinematic experience of my life. Many of the main avenger's character arcs that have spanned for years come to a perfect conclusion that is epic, intense and incredibly emotional. The 3 hours fly by as comic book fans and casual viewers alike are on the edge of their seat wondering how this decade long saga will come to an end. The fact that these superhero characters in sci fi costumes have the ability to make so many grown men cry is a testament to the success marvel studios has had in bringing these characters to life. Robert Downey Jr., Scarlett Johanson, Chris Evans, Tom Holland, Gwyneth Paltrow, Jeremy Renner, Karen Gillian and Elizabeth Olsen stand out the most to me with their powerful and emotional performances.

Living long enough to see my childhood heroes come to life on the big screen is quite a dream come true. That said, the culmination of a decade of the MCU has spoiled me rotten. Endgame leaves me feeling a bit hollow. Yes, the opening act subverted our expectations in a fulfilling way, and the third act was epic on many levels. Watching Thanos punch that Captain Marvel wannabe in her smug gob with the power stone was particularly poetic. However, I feel the heavy-handed fan service was equally gob-walloping in retrospect. And I think the lazy writing engendered more questions for fans than it answered, as evidenced by the litany of post hoc explanations offered by the co-directors. In short, it lacked some of the intricacy and heart that made Infinity War so enthralling.

I would highly recommend this movie to people that have seen infinity war or have been caught up with the MCU. The greatest things about this movie have to be the relationships of each characters and how they interact with each other. The camerawork of this movie is absolutely stellar and it is a visual treat from start to finish. The damage that infinity war had for this movie made it feel like that in general these movies can bring new scenarios of where the main hero doesn't always HAVE to win and there are consequences for not winning which brings more narrative weight to the actions and can be suspenseful of how our main heroes are going to get out of this one! I'd say the humor in this movie is also a step up from some of the humor of the earlier films which is a delight and can help with easing the tension. This movie like infinity war brings forth emotional moments, and intense moments. I had a small issue, the pacing in certain areas feels rushed but it doesn't ruin the movie!

It does what it should and what is expected, it messes around with things like time travel casually without any consequences as if it was a parody or comedy of greater time travel films and it is just as bland, messy and illogical as Infinity War. 
However it is far more enjoyable than Infinity War because they just play it out as a bit of everything this time, the story is serious stuff about the fate of half the universe and blah blah blah... but it is fun to watch and it is entertaining. 

There are too many negative things about it to summarise without out seeming negative toward Marvel films... and too few genuine positive to balance it up. 
So it sits somewhere better than Age of Ultron and Infinity War and not was good as Avengers. And that is okay, because to me the Avengers films were never why Marvel's Cinematic Universe works... it is the individual heroes and actors who really are interesting and their story arches that makes it great. Endgame celebrates that in their nostalgic time travel escapades and the actor do really well in all the mess of that. Also Cap and Stark get their ending here in a satisfying and memorable way, unlike other side characters.

The MCU once again flexes its box-office breaking formula with the final installment of The Avengers franchise. While the screenwriters desperately try to write themselves out of a corner with incomprehensible rules about the space-time continuum?, they ultimately present a heartwarming, bittersweet film packed with an absolutely charming ensemble cast. I say this about every Marvel film, but it is impossible to sit through the MCU's confontational fight scenes, with such intricate choreography, epic music and witty one-liners, without having a massive grin on your face.

This film was so brilliant that I had to see it a second time in theaters. It was able to invest in its characters in a way that Avengers Infinity War didn't which made for a much better emotionally-charged film. The acting was stellar. I felt as if I was in the mindset of the characters and their motives were clear. The plot was pretty easy to follow despite some plot holes in the time travel aspect. The action was the best part of the movie aside from the comedy. The third act of a Marvel movie usually is the part where it all goes south, but surprisingly, the climax was entertaining and wasn't just a bunch of explosions meant to entertain those who only want to see their characters kick ass. Sure. There is plenty of that, but they did it correctly and the climax had a meaning to it. The movie did seem very slow in the first act, but it picked itself up gracefully. I would see this in theaters a third time, if I could.

Infinity War did something that no Marvel Studios film had done before: the villain won. At the end of the film, Thanos dusted half the life in the universe. We were left on a somewhat unfulfilled note at the end of the movie, and that continues right into Endgame.

The trailers and promotions for the film were deliberately vague, as it is difficult to talk about the core premise of the movie without spoiling it. Instead, I'd like to focus on the huge number of cameos and references this movie has. Almost every single MCU film gets at least a small nod here, which is to be expected for this big finale event. Everyone gets to have their moment (some more than others), and there is a healthy amount of fanservice, especially toward the third act.

The first act of the movie is verrrrry slow. Perhaps we have been spoiled, having grown accustomed to a big action set piece within the first 20 minutes of a Marvel film. There is an action sequence, but it is very anticlimactic, and leaves you feeling much as you did at the end of Infinity War, but at the wrong time. It seems they were trying to slow-roll the feeling of hope throughout the movie, but I felt we spent too much time at the bottom of the ladder.

There are many satisfying moments, and everyone is given their due by the end of it.

A beautiful ending to a long series of movies.

Absolutely trash for Marvel standards. It's lazy and the only reason why it was good was the CGI and most of the charater development. But even that wasn' the best. BTW, this review contians from here on out. Captian Marvel was pretty good, only for the action sence. Only than that, her story wasn't that good. Got to expect that from her movie. When Iron Man and Nebula were stuck in space, and was the main anticipation from the first trailer, I wanted to know what will happen to him. But they spoiled it in the next trailer I was forced to watch. It was an ad on YouTube and showed that spoiler. So the next best thing was "how do they survive?" This is a story arc that has so much potential. Nebula could learn to trust people, or Tony's engineering could of been put to the test, but NO! Captian Marvel just flew up to the ship and saved them. Since I was anticipating so much for this, it left an unsatisfying feeling. So much for "satisfying finale" in the Critics Consensus. Also, look, Tony invented time travel out of the blue. How did he invent it? How does it work? Who cares?! Everything in the beginning is rushed and trash so far. Then a rat saved Ant-Man. All of the beginning is rushed. But him being saved by a rat could of silped under my radar this time, because he can't really have a story arc, or progress the plot in the quantum realm. But with all of this lazyness combian, who cares?! Then the most anticipated moment of them all, fighting Thanos. That was a big twistm and was a good one (in a story standpoint). Then there was the dramatic 5 ysars later. Pixar was known for showing, not telling. But clearly that wasn't the case. And it definitely affected most of it. I had no idea what to expect, and in a bad way. How are cities like? Did people get over their losses? Clearly, I had know idea. The 5 years later was a dramatic one, but it really didn't help the story. They could of put one year later, and then show the progress of the cities. Just. More. Lazynees. But after this point, I have to say, it was pretty good. Revisiting past movies was AWESOME. Fight sences were Marvel standards. And I would of said this made up for everything. But the ending isn't the best. The "whatever it takes to deliver a satisfying finale" in the critics consensus feel more of a lie. Tony dying and "completing" his story arc, didn't actually feel complete. He just died with a kid he never got to raise and wasn't satisfying at all. All the critical reviews are really true, and that's a problem.

Before I get into the nit-picking of this film, I want to make it clear that I thoroughly enjoyed myself in the theater. The movie got off to a perfect start and had me on the edge of my seat, and the ending was probably the best thing I’ve ever seen in a theater. Overall, I loved it. It was emotional, truly shocking, and the PERFECT ending to this 20+ movie saga. Marvel did a great job with this franchise and they should be proud of creating a universe with this much depth and development, it’s a truly remarkable feat!                

But there were a lot of things I didn’t love: 

Firstly, I think that everyone can agree the biggest drawback of Endgame was the lack of fighting. It took up until the final 40 minutes of the film for any real fight to break out. Up until then, it was mostly just story with no real action or risk whatsoever, which REALLY made the the second act drag. Which is fine, because story development is important, but being a superhero movie it was really disappointing we had to wait almost 2 hours and 30 minutes for any fight scene to occur (minus the cap vs cap fight which was decent at best, but definitely not a substitute for the lack of action).

Secondly, I hated what they did to Thor. Being my favorite character in the MCU, I was really disappointed with how they utilized him in Endgame. Instead of using all the remorse he was filled with from Infinity War as fuel, they channeled it in a completely different direction and made him somewhat of a loser. Now I’m not saying that being upset or depressed over a failure is something to be looked down upon, but for a character like Thor it made no sense to me. He had pretty much lost everything near and dear to him over the course of the MCU, but it never affected him to the point that he had given up on everything including himself, so it made no sense to me that he would suddenly change everything about himself and become far. I also felt like he was TOO comedic and wasn’t serious enough. I may be alone on this but I just didn’t understand why the Russo’s chose to go this route with such a powerful and mentally strong character. It felt like everything Taika Waititi did in Ragnarok was just thrown down the drain and all of the development of the character was wasted. I enjoyed the joke at first, but I wanted to see Thor return back to his headstrong and confident self, which sadly didn’t happen. 

Finally, my last issue arose with none other than the Incredible Hulk. My issue, however. was not so much with the character’s role and personality in the movie, but rather the fact that he got less than 30 seconds of on screen fighting time. That’s right, we saw one of the most formidable and savage characters in the Marvel Universe fight on screen for less than 30 seconds. To me, this is one of the biggest failures of endgame. Hulk is one of the most well known, if not THE most well known, characters that Marvel has. At the end of the day, Professor or World Breaker, Hulk is Hulk and the fans want to see the angry green monster get some action which we really didn’t get in this movie at all. It would’ve been nice to see Banner get a rematch with Thanos or even get a crack at one of the members of the black order. Some more backstory on his transition to professor hulk would have been nice as well. But otherwise, I really liked his role and importance to the story (something I felt was absent in previous Avengers films) and I’m excited to see this new persona play out in future films! 

So in conclusion, Endgame to me wasn’t perfect like I thought it would be and I think there were a lot of things that could’ve been changed to make the film better. 

Regardless of all of these nitpicks, however, I still loved the film. So many moments and aspects of the film were done perfectly and had my draw dropping: 
•Thanos getting decapitated by Thor in the first 15 minutes which was then followed by a 5 year jump
•Seeing Tony Stark’s daughter for the first time
•The reveal of Prof. Hulk
•Seeing Valkyrie, Meek and Korg
•Fat Thor (even thought it was bittersweet)
•The Ancient One Cameo
•Thor getting Mjolnir back
•Tony getting to say bye to his dad
•The Trinity vs Thanos
•The Return of the dead Avengers
•Cap Wielding Mjolnir 
•Old Cap
and of course, everyone’s favorites
•”AVENGERS!..... assemble!”
•”And I.... am.... Iron Man”

I would definitely recommend seeing this movie, one of the most memorable moments of my life in a theater!

Final Rating: 9.1/10

I enjoyed it though not my favorite film BUT I think they deserve an academy award for special achievement. It truly is amazing what they accomplished. For decades to come people will study what they did. Marvel, a company that declared bankruptcy in 1996, had to sell off some of its known characters and now has a fighting chance to own the highest grossing film of all time built from their lesser known characters. I don't believe another shared universe will ever succeed the way Marvel did.
Footnote: I think the people who need to learn the biggest lesson from this is Star Wars and Disney. When they bought Marvel they said "keep doing what you're doing" and the passionate heads at Marvel succeeded in their long term goal of giving fans something truly satisfying, but when Disney bought Star Wars Disney said "let's do whatever, because people will pay money no matter what" and then they made that terrible movie.

5 stars for the movie that was released in April 2019. One star for the version released in late June 2019. The April release delivered on everything a movie could have weaving in all the different story lines and characters. The June 2019 re release was supposed to add in surprises, extra footage, end credits scene. It didn't. There was a Stan Lee tribute and a Spider Man Far From Home scene that we've seen half of in the trailer. VERY disappointing. I didn't see any additional footage beyond that. 
When seeing a movie more than once you start to notice holes in the plot. For instance, Thanos' whole premise doesn't make any sense. The world population in 1970 was half of what it is today. Why would wiping out half of the population help us? Is there mass starvation and suffering from lack of food? Not with commercial agriculture. So how could this genocide help a population? Especially wiping out half of all the livestock etc. Makes no sense... I of course didn't question it the first time I saw the movie.

Everything that was and is wrong with Marvel comics displayed on the big screen. Retconning to substitute for any requirement to create a plot, shoehorning major characters to build momentum for other Marvel spin-offs, and a shameful push of "girl power" to undermine current issues by appearing to be supportive. I will give credit to the film for being amusing in the domestic scenes that show superheroes being regular ol' people; whether wallowing, drinking problems away, or just hanging out. Otherwise, it doesn't deserve the fanfare or praise.

The first time I saw this movie, I didn't like it at all because I thought there was better directions that Marvel could have gone with the film. However, after watching it a couple more times, it truly does feel like a thank you letter to the fans that have stuck around since the beginning and have been going to watch the MCU unfold for 11 years. I am lucky enough to call myself one of those people and Avengers: Endgame has now become my favorite MCU film. There is so much emotion and excitement in this film and I truly hand it to Joe and Anthony Russo. They weren't just asked to create a satisfying closure to Endgame or Infinity War, they were asked to bring a closure to a franchise with 22 movies in it. The fact that that they even succeeded a little is really impressive. What makes it even more impressive is that this film didn't just succeed a little, it shattered box office records and became a fan favorite. If anyone is planning to watch Endgame that enjoys Marvel but has not seen all of the movies, I encourage you to watch all of the movies before Endgame, because you will have a spectacular and mind blowing experience if you do.

"Avengers Endgame" truly does feel like the end of the MCU as we know it, and what a movie to end the first 22 films of this incredible franchise. Of course there will be more Marvel movies to come, and I have faith in Marvel that they will continue to make spectacular and fun movies, but I do have a hard time seeing them being able to come close to the closing salvo that was "Infinity War" and "End Game". Every actor gives a strong performance, with the stand out being Robert Downey Jr. who gives one of the finest performances in a blockbuster film that we will ever see. Highly recommended, and a must see for fans of Marvel.

This movie is absolutely amazing!! When I first watched it I was in such a state of shock I couldn’t control my excitement!! But there is something I must say about this movie. When Avengers: Infinity War came out I wanted to see it in theaters but I didn’t. In fact I didn’t see Infinity War until the day I saw Endgame. On April 27, 2018, there was a car accident in my hometown. I didn’t find out until 2 days after the crash that a friend of mine was involved. When I found out about my friend she had 3 hours until they pulled the plug on her life support. She died the next day. Then when Endgame came out on April 26, 2019, I looked at tickets just to see how popular it would be and saw 1 ticket for it!! I snagged that ticket faster than a super soldier can run!! But what I didn’t realize until after I had purchased my ticket was that I was going to see Endgame on April 27, 2019, exactly 1 year after the crash that took my friend. I went anyway and saw Infinity War for the first time right before I went. And Endgame helped me get the closure I needed after my friend’s death. Walking out of the theater after the movie was pure bliss. I felt like myself again!! And now I can watch Infinity War without feeling like I’m responsible for what happened!! I can watch it and just enjoy the movie and not blame myself for my friend’s death!! When Endgame comes out for purchase you can bet you bottom dollar that I will get both Infinity War and Endgame!!

This movie was mind blowing! I honestly was not expecting much. What I got was so much more than a movie with super heroes it was a movie that transcended time. I loved all my old heroes and my new ones in one movie that was so incredible!

Comic book basically was something that surrounded my childhood. I remember getting my allowance and walking hours to the nearest comic shop store to follow Marvel West Coast Avengers, Spider-Man, Hulk, Wolverine and Chris C's writing on the X-men. Now years later I met Stan Lee in person and saw 
Avengers: Endgame in IMAX 3D and in 4Dx. This film perfectly wraps up every story arc from the past MCU movies and brings the journey of the six original Avengers either full circle, a demise, or a happy ending. Exept where is Quicksilver? Why didn't Scarletwitch absolutely mention they should bring her brother back from the dead? Only really a few things bothering me about this film. I really was hoping to see a 'homage' to Grey Hulk or an angry furious Hulk fighting Thanos for the second time. Rather then where that character of Hulk was sort of sidelined and confirmated in smarts alone. We also never had the pleasure of seeing a real life version on Hawkeye's original Hawkeye mask. I'm sure a realistic way of emplimenting this can be included in someway. This could have been shown so it can be passed down to his daughter later on in future content.

I think Hawkeye's scenes at beginning of the movie (when his family was dusted) and when he was fighting bad guys in Japan were unnecessary. Why? Because the prequel, Infinity War, had already shown the aftermath of Thanos snap. With that, it is understandable that people are sad, so it serves no purpose to show how this drove Hawkeye mad and end up killing bad guys in Japan. Instead, these scenes should be replaced with longer fighting scene when Thanos and his troops arrived on Earth. The fighting scene is the most crucial part which get the audiences' adrenaline pumping. Perhaps it should include fighting scene between Marvel superheroes with Children of Thanos such as Ebony Maw & Proxima Midnight. Maybe MCU should shoot this and relaunch an extended version. Pretty sure if this happens, Endgame will easily cross US$3 billion mark worldwide.

Perfect end to a perfect saga of films, yes there was an abundance of gratuitous fan service, but to a degree that's what these films have become about. The character arcs that ended were brought to a close appropriately and in a satisfying manner, others still left plenty of room for further development, and hints were dropped to the future of the MCU post-phase 3, not so much that we know exactly what to expect, but also not so little that we're completely in the dark, just as Marvel have done so well over the past 11 years. It does everything a second of a 2 part story should, picks up immediately from where we left off, with our heroes at their lowest, gives the bitter taste of the Infinity War aftermath a chance to sink in, and then breathes fresh impetus into the remaining heroes when it seems like all hope is lost, culminating in a quite simply thrilling final battle. The focus is redirected towards the Avengers themselves, after the preceding film had mainly focussed on Thanos as almost the main protagonist, there were moments where the scale felt a little uneven, due in part to the attempt to balance the reduction of the primary cast to a select few with the expanded timescale of the film at nearly three hours, but it was definitely discernible as a three act epic film, and whilst I think Infinity War is the better picture, Endgame gives us far more satisfaction overall.

Otherwise, great work.

I originally pegged this as the worst MCU movie until "Eternals" came along.
This film had so much potential but what it ended up actually having was so many cinema sins, you'd need a calculator with an exponents button to count them.
Ultimately, "Endgame" had three huge problems. First, the first 2 hours were an absolute bore. People around me literally fell asleep. I probably would have too if I wasn't fuming mad. Second, the time travel explanation was far less plausible than in "Back to the Future" (even though "Endgame" tried to diss "Back to the Future"). "Alternate timelines" is too hokey to suspend your disbelief but it sure gives Kevin Feige lots of future storylines to play with. (And btw, why so easily dismiss the legit proposal to go back in time to kill Thanos when he was born?) Third, the fight scenes with Thanos were not believable. Stormbreaker in "Infinity War" could break the power of six Infinity Stones (think about that!), but in "Endgame" it couldn't even break a simple metal weapon wielded by a Thanos with zero Infinity Stones (and that same metal weapon could also inexplicably break Vibranium...mm hmm, convenient). And naturally, heroes only take on Thanos one at a time. 
But wait...there's more! Whiny Fat Thor is unlikeable. Professor Hulk (who also was borderline unlikeable) was inexplicably MIA during the big fight. Iron Man's sendoff lacked any emotion. Captain America's ending seemed selfish and contrary to his character. Humor was fatally lacking. Gratuitous gay partner mention. Did I mention unrealistic fight scenes?
A letdown of Infinity proportions.
I enjoyed how the storyline takes you back to all the older movies. Great fighting scenes through out the movie. My kids watch the movie 2 times.

one of the worse A movies. In general presence of ultimate superhero (like Marvel) creates an awkward limitation - she can solve any conflict but doesn't because she's ... busy elsewhere! Wow. Such originality! 

AND as a nerd, I refuse to accept the logic of single timeline surviving the destruction of past Thanos in the future (that's a major logic flaw). But the most sacrilegious was the fact that Cap took possession of Thor's hummer. Seriously? decades of philosophical debates resulting in this?

Lastly - the last fragment of the movie was for totally dumb people. I mean is there anyone who couldn't piece together that aging Cap decided to make America Great Again (different America) and stay with his girlfriend? I mean next time they should RE-PE-AT words so we'd better understand the plot.
All though I was a little unhappy with the end.

Endgame is the culmination of 22 films in the MCU and bringing an end to the stories of some characters. The film takes a focus on the survivors of "The Snap" and the original six Avengers. Some characters such as Captain Marvel and Okoye are barely in it, but the film makes up for it by heavily featuring Iron Man, Captain America, Ant-Man, Hulk, Hawkeye, Black Widow, Thor, Rocket, Nebula, and War Machine. It creates a visceral adventure that highlights the major moments of the MCU so far and sets up future instalments. The final hour is some of the greatest moments ever put to screen and will create a truly memorable and moving adventure that will more than meet even the most sceptical fan's expectations.

Everyone raved about Endgame I felt like someone standing on the side devoid of any emotions wondering "what is wrong with me?" ... Don't get me wrong. I liked the film, and loved Infinity War. But I thought the direction it took was disappointing. 

This obsession with a great massive battle is what ruined it for me. Why does Marvel insist on epic battles now? It never started out that way. Ironman was perfect in that it was a small internal strife to deal with (btw, the whole plot of Ironman is that other nations will try and build their own battle armour but after 20 years they still haven't?) 

The shouldn't have pulled Thanos into the current timeline like they did. I like that he was mixed in some how, but it should have been subtle event. The whole closed time line scenario is brilliant. I was was happy. It's rare for a show to get time travel right. There are only a few directions one can correctly follow, and Avenger's started that so well. But than they had to have Thanos come through. Maybe it would've been interesting if it was just a handful of them and the reset returned him memory-less, but the entire ship and army? ... I'm sorry but this looses stars.

There's nothing original about Avengers: Endgame, but you have to give praise to the Russo brothers for once again leading this film into a smooth blended mixture of conflict, unity, nostalgic, unique humour and tearful reunions and goodbyes.
Picking up where infinity war left off, the film is steadily constructed into a unique masterpiece, one major moment highlight the resolved conflict between Tony Stark and Steve Rogers, but another of hawkeye's assassin lifestyle after losing his family.
The moment after five years when they reunite, you can they tell the surviving avengers are about to risk it all and that is the last time for the avengers to assemble.
A new adaptation of hulk gave a fresher feel into the movie, Thor's depression has transformed into somewhat a broken yet hilarious creation who grieves after failing to save everyone but hoping he's still worthy.
The most prominiment moment is Scott describing 2012 Steve' suit as ‘America's Ass'
A moment that will not be forgotten and which every avenger contributed to all the emotions leading up to this.
It's a rare movie in which just when you think everything is resolved, Ebdgame proves you wrong and throws the next surprise. This is expressed when all the disappeared avengers come back to fight against Thanos's army, in which the final moment which Steve gives the ‘Avengers Assemble' charging into the final chilling moments of the rest of the movie.
The most shattering finale reveals Tony Stark taking the sacrifice to save everyone. In what started the MCU with Robert Downley Jr's iron man, it's the final moment in which tugs our heartstrings that the Tony Stark we knew has ultimately overcomes his fear and his comfort to pull off the greatest emotional moment in MCU or perhaps of the decade.

Avengers End Game the 23rd movie in the MCU ( Marvel Cinematic universe) bring you an exciting, joyful, funny and heartbreaking movie. While almost 11 years of making movies this movie bring the best ending you can think, also new openings to the next movies.
 
Endgame begins with a reminder of what was lost in the previous film. The movie starts off with moments after Infinity war,  showing us the avenger, not in the last one Hawkeye and shows us what he loses. The Movie continues to a shot in outer space showing us a lost spaceship and showing us how the lost avengers came back to earth. Then they show how nothing could be changed. Then Five years later Ant-Man comes back shocking the Avengers with an idea which gives the heroes the lost hope. They re-assemble the team with the help of tony stark. They accomplish the goal and gain what is needed. Then it leads to an astonishing battle with all the heroes vs the villains army where the special effects are through the roof. You get everything you ever wished for in this battle. Then it ends with an epic plot twist and sadness.
    This movie is easily a 9.3/10 it a tremendous movie with a lot of work put into it and came out to be a terrific movie making about 7.1 billion dollars making the second most amount a movie has made at the box office. This movie is the perfect movie has all the things humor, adventure, sci-fi. It also has many easter eggs only the comic book readers would get. This movie shows how one comic book made by Stan Lee was much more, it was the whole universe.

Every movie leading to Endgame successfully met the requirement to have a decent plot only for Endgame to create a shamble. Despite Rotten Tomatoes giving it a generous approval rating, it was honestly at best a 2/10. I don't even know where to begin but here is a list of a couple of issues I had *SPOILERS*: 

No grieve/connection with the death of Tony Stark as the movie proceeded to direct its attention back to Captain America 

The killing of Thanos early on in the film and the introduction of one from a different timeline who did not know anything that happened in Infinity War left a sour taste in my mouth. Even if it was necessary, it was a swift and emotionless death. It was from then that I knew this movie would not be so great. 

What exactly was the purpose of Captian Marvel? Her standalone movie (I felt) did pretty well and I expected her to have a bigger purpose in Infinity War but all she really did was save Tony Stark -> Dipped -> returned to destroy Thanos ship? 

I would say some of the bright spots I saw throughout the movie was the character development of Ant-man and Nebula as well as the aminations towards the fight scene(s). Nebula I felt was a very important factor towards making sure the 'New Thanos' understands what happened in Infinity War. Without her, this would have been a total shitshow.

Despite the fact that they were super heroes the movie displayed the very essence of the human nature in their characters.  Thanos was all about what was right for a perfect universe.  The Avengers displayed what was good for it.  Might may be right but only for singular conquests.  The Avengers showed that goodness will conquer all.  They all could have chosen to keep what they had and ignore the rest, as we humans a lot of times choose to do, but what makes them super is that they choose to sacrifice and to serve, especially Iron Man.  I thought the movie was great.  Didnt go into it looking for flaws, rather the opposite went into it looking for something good and it was there.  Do the same.  Be inspired.

Putting it out there right from the get-go, Avengers: Endgame is my favourite MCU movie. It's my favourite movie of the year too, but I've only seen like ten or so 2019 releases, and this is the 22nd Marvel Cinematic Universe film, so that seems far and away the bigger deal. I can't say it's perfect, there's some conflicting stuff within its own runtime that really doesn't seem to gel (though a re-watch may prove me wrong on that), and it's not like every moment was the no-holds-barred-zero-exception best version of that moment from start to end. But God I loved this thing.

I will say this though, the reason that I loved it, is this thing is fan service galore. If you do not care for the franchise's 21 movies preceding this point, then Endgame is not the movie to turn you around on that. That may come in a future installment, but this one is a culmination. It's the end of Infinity War but also Phase 3, but also a wrap-up and genuine ode to/send off for everything that Marvel has done over the past 11 years. That to me was incredible, and I am eternally greatful, but I cannot imagine it working for people who have no vested interest in these characters.

To me though? My first 9 out of 10 rating in three years.

[Spoiler Alert!!]
Marvel Avengers: Endgame was a great movie, including the carrier of the gauntlet, which was a debate with many potential viewers before the release of this movie.  Though there are some major issues that arise when creating a cinematic feature that brings you back to scenes within it's predecessor films.  One major issue is a change in the future, where there will be 2 Captain Americas, during the same time.  So, how do they not meet each other, especially when Captain America meets Margret Carter in the hospital within the movie Captain America: Winter Soldier.  Where is future Captain America at her deathbed, and why wasn't the picture older version of him.  Also, how does going back to the past, not affect the future at all when they teleport after their missions.  Another huge plot hole is, Iron Man and Nebula's ability to walk on earth after being in space for 22 days, umm muscular atrophy applies to this case.  How does a normal human being sustain so much damage to his left arm, shouldn't his arm just disintegrate after using the infinity gauntlet.  Only by being in denial that those extremely large plot holes, don't exist, does the movie feel enthralling.  All in all, sometimes there needs to be more realism even when creating a movie about super beings.  Though, the overall story was excellent, but it isn't perfect.

It was a thrilling movie full of twists and unexpected surprises. Exciting and emotional conclusion to the infinity saga the MCU has explored thus far. My issue with Endgame is how carelessly the Russo brothers treat some of the characters which the fans have grown to love over the years: from giving a Tony Stark a family for only 5 years only to kill him off at the end (which I agree was a wonderfully emotional scene, but vastly unfair), to the way the characters all seem to dislike each other and put each other down, to the way Thor's depression was handled. All the actors delivered brilliant performances, especially Robert Downey Jr and Scarlett Johansson. I left the movie theatre feeling exhilarated, but the more I thought about the movie, the less I liked about it.

Exciting, shocking and fun, Avengers: Endgame is a film with a fantastic direction by Anthony and Joe Russo, an exceptional screenplay by Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely, a beautiful soundtrack by Alan Silvestri, a magnificent cinematograph of Trent Opaloch, a fast-paced which makes the film looks like it has less than 181 minutes, flawless visual effects, very well choreographed and incredible action sequences and excellent performances from Robert Downey Jr., who deserves to be nominated for the Academy Award for his performance, Chris Evans, Mark Ruffalo, Chris Hemsworth, Scarlett Johansson, Jeremy Renner, Don Cheadle, Paul Rudd, Brie Larson, Karen Gillan, Danai Gurira, Benedict Wong, Jon Favreau, Bradley Cooper, Gwyneth Paltrow, Josh Brolin and all the actors who make special appearances. In short, Avengers: Endgame, in my opinion, was all I wanted and it's an epic movie that I'll never forget, and in addition, it's the best MCU movie, the best Marvel movie as a whole, the best superhero movie of all time, the best movie of 2019, the best action movie of all time and the best movie I've seen in my entire life

Full disclosure:  not a fan of Marvel Comics or SciFi however, overall, very entertaining movie, but almost 3 hours long...whew!

Comic book movies are very hard for me because I collected comics for many years and know the source material very well...just like when ppl read the book and say the movie is not up to snuff.  So I usually go into this genre with low expectations.  So when the whole MCU universe of movies started and were all done really well...I was like finally...a studio is reading the comics and actually following them.  So even though I like many scenes from Endgame and the movie overall... the last quarter of the movie is incredibly unplausible and it really bothered me after 10 yrs of excellent scripts.  So it sucks that they decided to kinda give me a bunch a Fox like B.S. and insult me and just want me to believe implausible crap.  There are too many issues to name but the one big one is once Thanos puts on the guantlet...GAME OVER...just like the last movie he wins bc he has the 6 most powerful things in the universe that only he's strong enough to command or ppl on his power level can use.  The fight is over, the snap is just a fun dramatic pause..but the power is immediate and it's over once he has it on...they should have never let him get it and at least the end would be somewhat plausible.  That being said I still love the smart ambition to say we're going to do this and it's going to take 10 yrs.  When most times Hollywood has no patience (ie: Justice League and DC movies) I loved the movies overall and it's still an incredible accomplishment in movie story arch's from Marvel.  Hopefully changing the timelines will allow Marvel to bring in the X-men since Disney has now bought Fox and all it's characters they had the rights too.  I'll suggest a huge story arch through all the character's movies with the villain Kang the Conqueror next.  I know you non-comicbook ppl don't know who he is but just Google him and you'll see how cool that story line could be and how it can just naturally work as a transition from Endgame.

Between 3 and 4 stars. It has many of the deffects of the saga (it comes with SPOILERS): Avengers act without thinking in consequences (what about waiting to Captain Marvel? Between the many brains present, nobody thought about connection of Nebula in her past; don't they think in getting more time-technology since the beginning? Does nobody speak with Nebula about what finally happened with Thanos and her sister?), almost creating more disaster than they pretend to fix. But I must recognize they save somehow some of the obstacles they put themselves (including justification of Strange behaviour, that, well, it's so, so, but at least says why Stark had to survive). What they do very good is to manage emotions, symbols, ideas which indicate the end of an era (sometimes it looks one of these chapters for summary of TV series, as "Best moments"), and how much all this work and stories have created, closing some of the arcs in logical ways. A little forced sometimes (fans of time travel are horrified) but, somehow, it works. It would say any of the first 2 Avengers movies was better, but it has additional points as the whole conclussion of an era.

The end of an era. Endgame had to be big, and that's exactly what it did. For the biggest comic book universe on the big screen, many of the films in the MCU have thus far hidden from some of the more comic booky traits such as time travel and multiverses. But Endgame delivers as possibly the most comic booky films to date. Unlike the overstuffed Infinity War, this film focuses on fewer characters and as a result each has a chance to shine and to do something meaningful, at least until the huge fight at the end. But perhaps most important, it focuses on the original Avengers and gives them a chance to play hero and in some cases, say goodbye. The visual effects have been better than some of the previous marvel movies and the action, whilst not necessarily better has been consistent with past ventures. The biggest shock is the emotion it evokes. As a moviegoer who doesn't generally get worked up during films, there are a couple of moments where there was a tear in my eye. It is bold and that boldness creates suspense and emotion. A fitting end to phase 3 and the Infinity Saga... At least it would have been if Spider-man Far from Home wasn't the official end.

If this had been the last MCU movie, period, then it would have been a satisfactory end to a cinematic adventure that spanned decades. But it isn't leaving me with enough to be excited for what the future holds.

This was a very good movie overall. It was a little long in the middle. No real need to have a 3 hour movie other than just hubris. Some parts are very inconsistent. First, how could Thanos hold off Thor, Captain America, and Iron Man all at once with out the Gauntlet while in Infinity War he was basically defeated by Thor alone. Seems like a weak argument. Second, I have no problem with the new found ability of Captain America and Thor's hammer. The issue is he was also able to throw and control lightning which is a power that does not come from the hammer. This power comes from Thor himself as shown in Ragnarok. Overall though a really good movie to reset the Marvel Universe. I just wish they were consistent with the powers and story line.

Overall, messy, overly long, convoluted, and SO VERY LONG. Civil War seems to be the high point of managing the large cast, and Infinity War did a better job setting up an engaging and believable narrative. End Game fails at both of those things and drags us through an insane run time doing it. Still, it lands some great moments and that the trademark MCU humor we all love is alive and well. Just ok... won't watch this one again.

A relatively satisfying ending to the storyline many of us have grown up with, it is still nevertheless overshadowed by its direct predecessor in the franchise’s timeline Infinity War. After the masterpiece that was IW, it feels as if Disney could have taken even more risks with Endgame, raise the stakes just a little higher. The plot holes that inevitably follow a timetravel-heavy plot also detract from the film’s impact somewhat. But overall, on spectacle and performances from all our favorite actors, Endgame deserves to stand with the best that the MCU has to offer.

I LOVED Avengers Infinity War. I loved it the first time I saw it and the past 3 times I’ve rewatched it. When exiting the theater I said “I don’t see how it could have been any better.” And my biggest fear for End Game, was that it could not possibly live up to part 1. Well, it didn’t. At 3 hours running time End Game fails in so many ways one can’t help but feel a better edit could have improved it. It’s such a mixed bag. To quickly sum up which characters storylines payed off: Iron Man. Cap. Ant man. Black Widow. Hawkeye. Now, I’ll list which characters storylines did not pay off: Hulk, Thor, Thanos and everyone else. Not the best ending to Infinity War, but not the worst. Some truly epic moments for Tony and Cap.

It is amazing what Marvel has done with their jump into live-action films. This capstone for the MCU brings together a large swath of their comic book characters and fulfills a satisfying 3 hours for anyone who has been following the prior films. As a stand alone film several people will be very lost, and will not understand several parts of the film.

All in all, the twenty-second of the vast cinematic universe that many know as the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU), has managed to deliver on the year long hype between "Avengers: Infinity War", and "Avengers: Endgame. Through many vague and undescriptive trailer footage and TV spots, the viewer was able gather a sense of what this movie was going to be: A story told through the Avengers' eyes as they desperately rebuild the earth to what it was pre-snap. The way that we as the viewers are plunged into the world of the MCU post-snap, we see the pain that was felt throughout their world, we see all of this through the eyes of the Avengers. This movie serves as a satisfying conclusion to many character arcs that have their outreach throughout entire movies, which is something that has only been rarely successful in many Hollywood movies. As of Joe and Anthony Russo's fourth MCU installment, it is to be said that they have not only made their impact known throughout the MCU, but the entire superhero genre as a whole.

Avengers Endgame is not as good as Infinity War. Is it a bad movie? Nah. Excessive. Yeah. Tonally inconsistent? Double yeah. But its a fun colorful movie. And a great send off to a set of characters whom we've been following the stories of for abouta decade now (cept for the Hulk who basically has been reduced to a neutered plot device who forgets how to smash.). For a three hour long movie I don't think alot actually happened in this movie. For all its grandiose its essentially "We must gather the magic rocks so we can undo what the evil space wizard did!". This simple dragged out plot can be forgiven because this is a character's driven story and boy does it have alot of 'em. But for as well written the characters are I cant say the dialogue is 100% stellar with serious and emotional moment's being undercut by witty sarcasm or the "stark snark" a style of humour that I don't personally appreciate but the others in my theatre seemed to enjoy it so who knows maybe I'm the one who's missing something. I give this movie 7.8/10.

An amazing finally to the Infinity Saga. Every Avengers' story has been building up to this movie and all of them end satisfactory, aside from one. I think the movie was perfect and I believe that length was perfect because, not only was it commemorating the sheer magnitude and magnificence that Kevin Feige and his team created, but it also gave us our final moments with some of our favorite characters. I think Tony, Steve, and Nat all had beautiful endings.
My only issues with the movie was most importantly, the fact that they stripped Thanos of all of his character development from Infinity War. Obviously he wouldn't be the broken man he was at the end of that movie, but I wish he wasn't all Mad Titan. My other issue was Hulk. I think they should've had Hulk's and Bruce's merging happen throughout the movie instead of just showing it, but I still like what they did. Also I wish Hulk fought with Thanos again, after what happened at the start of Infinity War.
Aside from that I think its a great movie and the second best, first being Infinity War which I believed had a much better story.

I'm looking at this movie holistically in terms of audience. Here's my breakdown:

For Marvel fans, this movie is a 10/10

For the regular moviegoer, this is a 5-6/10.

However, there's one problem with the movie that transcends audience: pacing. The movie starts off really slow, then Ant-Man shows up, and things get moving. From there, the pacing of scenes and sequences is more akin of Infinity War--where every scene kept the plot moving.

Epic, moving and beautifully executed, Avengers: Endgame most definitely delivers a stunning and satisfying finale. This is the culmination of 10 years of storytelling, and the Russo Brothers close it out with a bang. 

Surprisingly more meditative and emotional than it is action-heavy like Avengers: Infinity War, Endgame is very much a look-back for many of these characters at the journey they've been through together and where their next, and for some final, mission will take them. 

Splitting this film into three acts, I see it as this: Act One is sheer perfection; Act Two is a little bit choppy but entertaining nonetheless; Act Three is rousing, massive, epic and emotional, and delivers everything you'd hope for and more. It's not a wholly perfect movie, but it's certainly a damn good final chapter to an unforgettable journey.

Low expectations, low results. First off, f**k Captain Marvel she’s so damn cocky, she’s all talk and is used as an Ex Machina to save the day. The tension and arc between Thanos and the Avengers is completely beat to death due to the fact that the Thanos they fight is from the past, and lost all logical reasoning, and is now a big brute like and dumb TV show. There’s no emotional moments apart from the ending, which completely went against its own rules of time travel. SOOOO much filler. For a finale of an epic franchise like this, make a movie equal to or better than Infinity War. I recognized all the callbacks, but it’s hard to appreciate when fat MF Thor is bumbling around. I was hoping for a serious movie and Thor wasn’t comical at all. It was so distracting seeing the most powerful avenger in battle gear with a huge ass belly. No to mention, Thanos without the Infinity Stones is somehow more powerful than Thanos with. His sword makes ZERO SENSE, he’s untouchable, and makes everyone feel like a wimp. When he dies, I couldn’t care less, he wasn’t a mad titan, he was another damn Ex Machina like Nebula and Captain Marvel. Two stars

I was not a comic book fan, but Ive seen all the Marvel movies.  So I was dismayed at how over my head I was with this movie. I was in a state of, wait...what? from about a quarter of the movie in.  Time travel and its accompanying difficulties were not handled well, but just glossed over so that it took tremendous suspension of disbelief to buy in.  I admired Josh Brolin and Tilda Swintons acting.  Even Benedict Cumberbatch in his cameo was impressive.  The main characters, not so much.  I noticed that three stars on this review equals Meh, it passed the time.  Yes.  Thats how i feel about this loooong movie.

Road to Endgame Film 22/22 Avengers: Endgame The day has finally come. I saw it twice back to back in IMAX. Once in IMAX 3D, and once in IMAX 2D. It was honestly such a beautiful experience watching this film. Being a fan since the start and growing up watching every single marvel movie in theaters and seeing such a beautiful ending to the Infinity Saga was amazing. I recommend everyone to watch this film in IMAX because that extra 26% of screen is definitely worth it. Now on to the movie. No spoilers! Let me just say this movie blew me away and has finally taken my No. 1 spot for favorite Marvel film, and more than likely favorite film ever. The story is AMAZING! From the start of the movie you feel the pain and suffering from the devastating consequences from Infinity War. This movie has some of the most iconic movie moments ever! Without spoiling anything let me just say it’s definitely the best Marvel film ever! It has amazing CGI, cinematography, a beautiful score, and an amazing cast! I’m truly blow away! A mini-review for Avengers; Endgame.
by Marylyn Motherbear

The Avenger's Endgame would soon leave local theaters, and I felt a certain draw pulling me into this much anticipated movie, though truly it is not my first choice regarding genre. Still, I like to see the films that get a lot of attention by all facets of the public, especially the kids. I want to see what they are seeing, to stay somewhat in tune. And so, two grandkids and I went to see The Avengers Endgame.  These superhero adventure movies usually embed some good messages, and Endgame does not disappoint. The arc of failure and redemption, the quantum do-over that allows for personal healing, gives us a tender teaching for today's world of judgment, separation and hateful expression and actions. Forgiveness is the operative. Not of the Other, but of the Self. 
In Endgame, we experience the everyday person that lives in the super hero. Said an alternative way, it is the super hero that is alive in the everyday person. Along side this profoundly human tale, there is a courageous and spiritual story, one that takes into a a multi-verse of our own existance, a chance for another take into Being Self, an homage to the superhero in us, in each person.  It brought tears to my eyes and fullness to my heart.
In the final analysis, it is a Eulogy and Homage for sure, for Stan Lee, and for all the heros who choose to be in service to saving the world. It is, however, not the end-as-we-know-it, but a far-flung quantum trail into parallel worlds where we live life as we will and our dreams come true.

(26APR2019) Nothing like this has happened in the history of art.

(02MAY2019) "I am inevitable."

In 2007, the very idea of Marvel Comics making their own movies was laughable. They chose "Iron Man" as their first attempt; they couldn't use Spider-Man, the Fantastic Four, or the X-Men. The casting of Robert Downey, Jr was inspiring, but only to those who knew the character. To the rest of the world, he was an addict and therefore a potential problematic actor to work with. To direct this movie, they picked Jon Favreau, who had done "Elf," hardly an example to submit when applying to direct an action movie.

Then, with the one-two punch of successes of "Iron Man" and "The Incredible Hulk" (yes, that was a success), the experiment of a multi-film franchise following different characters but SET IN THE SAME UNIVERSE went underway, culminating in 2012's The Avengers. The successes of all of these movies have created this Mandela effect remembering an inevitable long-term plan that has led up to Avengers: Endgame.

But despite the reality of the riskiness of this entire franchise, the world has come to accept that the success of Endgame is an inevitability, meaning that the standard for success is unbelievably high. And yet, Endgame succeeds and then some.

This movie (and the others before them) isn't meant to instruct or educate. Yes, Captain Marvel, Black Panther, Winter Soldier, and Civil War tackle some pretty heavy cultural issues with regards to racism, sexism, government oversight, paranoia, and xenophobia, but that doesn't mean that those messages can't also be part of an entertaining experience. With Endgame, it's about grief, life, family, and living.

The key to this movie's success is the respect it pays to the entries that came before it. It pays respect by treating the other movies as reference points, to the degree that even character's orchestral theme songs are heard; these themes aren't recycled, they're paid homages.

It is a testament to the power of this franchise (from the studios, to the performers, to the directors, to the musicians) that the emotions that are elicited from watching this movie are felt through disparate audiences worldwide. How powerful must a work of art be when audiences outside the U.S. cheer and roar in support of a man decked out in the stars and stripes and is named "Captain America?!"

This movie was an absolute perfect end to a 10 year culmination of films within the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU). The MCU has always been at their A game with team up movies and this is just another perfect example of it. The Russo's, Feige, and all the actors did a wonderful job with the making of this film.

Amazing wrap-up to the 11 years and 22 movies in the MCU. Looking forward to the future phase 4 onwards. Well acted and probably the best ever performances from Downey, Evans, Gillan and Johansson. Many callbacks and fan service to die hard fans but well spent fan service.

I really disliked the ending of this movie. I wanted a truly happy ending. I was hoping for something similar to a Return of the Jedi feeling for the ending and didn't get it. Tony Stark deserved better than this. 

Also - the scene with all women warriors helping Captain Marvel who had just taken out a spaceship single handedly? She needed these other wonderful women why exactly? And wasn't it darling for Peter Parker to set up the scene for them? I am woman hear me roar? Is that what that was? Gawd. 

I did like that Iron Man was the one to make things right. And the scenes with the original Avengers talking with each other - those were good scenes - old school - I would have liked more of that - especially in a 3 hour movie. 

The final battle - what a mess. Marvel has done better - and should have done better with this. I'm learning that maybe I shouldn't watch Marvel on the big screen anymore - just wait for it to come to one of the streaming channels. What happened, Marvel? You used to be an "E Ticket."

And then came ENDGAME, and nothing could be ever be the same. (at least in the superheros universe)
This production represented an end of an era, on its shoulders there was a lot of responsibility to carry, therefore expectations could not have been higher: and we have a win! I am so glad to write that we do have a win.
ENDGAME is exactly how it should be: emotional, funny, entertaining, definitive and conclusive; but what really count is how we got to this point, which is with 10 years of hard works, awesome characters and well written stories, and if it's true that action movies come, artistically speaking, with limitations, it is also true that ENDGAME just moved those boundaries.
There are no words to describe this movie! Just be prepared for the feels, laughs, and anger.

It pains me to give this movie a 3.5, but that's the rating I think it deserves. I LOVE superhero movies, and I love the MCU, but this movie (although good) does not do a good job of explaining itself and making sense. Fat Thor is funny, but at the end of the movie, ***SPOILER*** he's fighting Thanos (sans Infinity Stones) with both Mjolnir and Stormbreaker, and he can't beat him (this is also with 2 other superheroes fighting Thanos alongside him). Captain Marvel shows up at the VERY end and blows up Thanos' ship in like 2 seconds -- WTF?? Time travel questions. Seriously, none of it makes sense. This pains me, but they almost made Thanos just as strong without Infinity Stones as he was with them. It makes no freakin' sense. Cap time travel questions... In the end he gives his shield to .... Falcon??? How will he even carry it?? Bucky makes the most sense. Stupid SJW crap. It pops up and ruins everything. Infinity War was solid. This, unfortunately, is not as good. There are moments that are great if you've watched all the MCU films before, but, overall, this movie is a bit lackluster.

If Infinity War was the Victory Lap for Disney's Marvel Universe, then Endgame is the afterparty where everyone needs to be reminded that there will be other races at a later date. Perhaps a bit of a stretched metaphor, but the truth of it is none the less apparant in a lot of unnecessary fluff scenes, character changes and superfluous characters that had been better left for later incarnations of the Marvel Universe movies. Layered on top is a trite Deus Ex Machina that goes deep into spoiler territory, but which will be divisive for a lot of people, and you have a movie that falls short of it's potential.
Despite it's shortcomings, Endgame is still an excellent movie that any Marvel fan is sure to see and remember for decades to come, with plenty of funny moments and epic fight scenes.

If you want to see a movie with few original ideas but great execution, this is your film.  Without spoiling anything, I will say that I thoroughly enjoyed several parts, and virtually everything with RDJ or Chris Evans was absolutely fantastic.  The rest of the Cycle One actors had great roles as well and played them brilliantly, but those two clearly had the largest roles to play.  Wonderful to see characters from Thor: Ragnarok getting a cameo as well - some of my favorites.  That said, I would have enjoyed just a tiny spark of the unexpected.  This film felt like the outcome was inevitable from the beginning, which really cut the drama.  Note to Marvel Studios:  don't advertise follow-up films for characters that are dead until after they are brought back...  it kind of ruins it.

I was expecting more based on all the other Avengers. This one really just summed up every Marvel character and gave us closure. It did have its moments, Joy with everyones return, especially the reunion with Spiderman & Tony, sadness at Tonys and Natashas death, warmth at Steve finally able to be with Peggy. In the first Avenger, Steve accused Tony of never doing anything for anyone but himself, in his death he finally showed his sacrifice and concern for others and put them above himself. I am looking forward to see what / who the next Avengers will be. Maybe, all female, Captain Marvel, Pepper, Shuri, Hawks daughter?? Meanwhile, I will look forward to more Black Panther, Dr. Strange (my favorite), Falcon (next Capt.) and Spiderman. All in all a great movie. Stan Lee would be proud!

An emotional roller coaster. I had to see it twice to process it all. How can you fairly judge a movie when 22 movies has preceded it? The fan service and payoff for Marvel fans is unprecedented in this movie. If you aren't a Marvel fan, unfortunately this movie will leave you a little confused and emotionally unaware during key plot points. But there are key character developments that occur that may upset Marvel fans (myself included). I wish more time could've been spent on these subversive developments to prepare fans. I was able to get over this on second viewing. I felt the beginning could have been paced better. Overall, movie doesn't feel like a 3 hour epic and I didn't want it to end. I hate accepting that this is the "endgame" and the MCU will move on in big ways. Bravo to everyone involved throughout this 11 year journey. Truly awe-inspiring the commitment and execution movie goers have witnessed. There may never be anything like this again.

Not sure what all the hype is about. The last movie left off with most of the heroes getting killed. I was just hoping they don't revive them via *roll eyes* "time travel", which of course they did. There's no point to any movie once you introduce time travel because if the outcome is not favorable, all you have to do is go back in time to take steps to prevent it. It's the ultimate lazy cheat. Add to that the fact that it's just a bunch of CGI and stunt doubles "fighting" *yawwwwn*. If you want good action, save the trip to the theater for John Wick instead.

What can I say about Avengers: Endgame other that how great it is with a marvellous cast and story that is very entertaining. This was just a perfect ending to conclude the main story of the Marvel Cinematic Universe while giving us a grand finale to some of our absolutely favourite characters. There are also some fantastic performances from Robert Downey Jr., Scarlett Johansson and Chris Evans. Josh Brolin as Thanos is probably the best movie villain ever with the most character development and a very intense feeling of risk when he was on the screen. Avengers: Endgame will go down in history as one of the biggest and best movies of all time!
Action, funny, and twist and turns.

Endgame takes on a bigger task than any prior film of any genre has ever attempted: pull together and complete the storylines from eight different film franchises, 22 films, and dozens of major characters. Is it flawless?  No.  It it a magnificent and moving finale?  Beyond any question or challenge. If you don't like Endgame, you are never going to like any superhero movie.  This is the capstone to the greatest action series ever produced, and it is highly unlikely that Hollywood will ever again even attempt to bring together such a huge story. As a lifetime fan of Marvel I am deeply grateful.  Real Frantic One. Keeper of the Flame. Quite Nuff Sayer. Titanic True Believer. Permanent Marvelite Maximus.

Avengers Endgame is an absolute must-see for all. It features a well-structured plot, little bits of humor, and a final battle that will give you chills. This movie will manipulate your emotions with its humor, heart-breaking moments, and moments that will have you cheering and jumping out of your seat. However, be warned, this is a 3 hour long movie. It seems the only good times to go use the restroom are when the San Francisco title appears on the screen, when Hulk goes to lunch, and when the title New Jersey is shown. These are also all in the first half of the movie, although the New Jersey one might be cutting it close to the second half. Overall, an absolutely phenomenal movie, but take caution if you have a weak bladder. (But it’s still worth it either way)

The writing was terribly weak, and the character development even worse. Having strong male and female characters come back as emotionally weak, and unable to process grief this resulting in not accepting changes in life which we ALL go thru was horrible. Moral given was those who move forward with grief are not as important as those who dont, resulting in people who process it and move thru it ending up loosong everything. Reminds me of entitled people who refuse to accept a decision and force change on those who accepted and moved on. Horrible thing to teach our children.
